1.content:
Ahreed Hussein was petrified. Sitting at a stainless steel desk, an empty chair opposite was the only other furniture in the brightly lit, windowless room. He'd been instructed not to look back at the large mirror behind him. For what seemed like hours now, he could still hear his heart pounding in his chest. Frantically he continued to try and think of some possible reason for his detention. What had he done? Who had he met? Was it someone he knew? Then again it might be Facebook, Twitter, email or a stupid text message to one of his friends.

He had not seen or heard of Baba, his dad, since that brief mobile call as he was taken from school. The day had started like any other school day, except after two periods of English he went to the school library during recess to work over a difficult, homework maths equation. His greatest fear to that point was his maths teacher, Mr Bhaduri in the afternoon. Though a fellow Muslim, Mr Bhaduri did Ahreed no favours. While working away at the back row of the library desks, Ms Cook the Librarian came over and asked him to go to the Principal's office after recess.

After he had waited outside the office for about ten minutes, he was summoned. Standing around the main desk were a man and a woman, talking to his Principal, Mr Waites. He had introduced them as Kirstin and Russell. Ahreed had noticed immediately that the man was much bigger than his Baba or his brother, Ahrou. The woman seemed young. Mr Waites had explained they were from the government and needed to speak with him.

They had talked to him about school life at the Kings School, his scholarship and his sporting interests. Then they began to explain about leaving, taking him with them! Immediately, Ahreed was alarmed. His Principal had encouraged him to call his dad, and Baba had simply said over the phone, "Trust me, my boy. Go with them. I will talk with you later."
1.title: Chapter 1

11.content:
Though the car the man Russell and the woman Kirstin bundled him into was ordinary, Ahreed realised immediately that the situation was serious. Afraid of the man who was driving, he turned to the young woman sitting next to him in the back seat. "Am I in some kind of trouble, Ms Kirstin?"

The woman looked out of the car window, smiling. "Why do you think that, Ahreed?" she asked, distantly.

Ahreed paused for a moment. "Because you are taking me away." The sound of the traffic outside filled the silence as she looked up at the rear vision mirror. Ahreed could see her eyes meet the man's as he drove.

"Where do you think we are taking you?" asked the woman, glancing back out of the passenger window. She seemed to be half ignoring Ahreed.

He looked down into his lap, feeling frustrated now, as well as frightened. Every question he asked was returned by another question. "How could I know, when you have not told me!?" he demanded, letting the woman know he was becoming impatient.

The woman smiled again, still staring distantly out at the bustling city of Sydney passing by.

Ahreed kept waiting for an answer. Neither the man nor the woman replied. Ahreed was afraid to ask any more questions. He looked around the car instead and noticed a sign stuck to the driver's visor. Ahreed realised it was a hire car.

The silver Commodore drove on, Ahreed noticing its entry to the M4. He recognized Paramatta, Strathfield and then Petersham pass by as his journey continued. He so wanted to ask about the destination, but his trust in the two strangers had been exhausted by the conversation leaving the Kings School. As the car turned towards Mascot and then approached the airport, his alarm bells really started to ring. Suddenly, he blurted out, "Where... where are you taking me?"

The woman beside him and the man driving kept ignoring him. The woman just reached into her handbag and took out a small tablet device, then started texting.

"This isn't fair!" protested Ahreed, "You can't do this!"

"Calm down, Ahreed," replied the woman, "We're just going on a quick flight to Canberra." Ahreed sat suddenly forward, looking out at the airport surrounds as if trying to find a bearing. The woman stretched out her arm and grabbed him by the shoulder, pressing him back into the seat. "Stay calm, Ahreed," she said, raising her voice slightly and placing her smartphone down on the next seat. "It's going to be alright...there's no need to be alarmed."

"But what is this!?" protested Ahreed. "You can't do this to me... this is Australia."
11.title: The journey from Kings School to ASIO

111.content:
The Kirstin woman moved her hand from Ahreed's shoulder to his hand. "Calm down, Ahreed. You will be back with your family tonight."

Ahreed felt confused again. "Why are you taking me to Canberra? How do I know you won't hurt me?"

"Because Ahreed," continued Kirstin, "This is Australia. You are an Australian. We will not hurt you. We simply need your help."

Too many thoughts were fleeting through Ahreed's mind. The most obvious question was who could he trust? He looked at Kirstin's eyes, then back down into his lap. Slowly, he asked again, "Why are you taking me away?"

The woman tried to gain back Ahreed's eyes. "Because we need your help, Ahreed... Australia needs your help. We have been helping you for the past few years and now we are asking you to help us."

Ahreed pulled his hand away from the young woman. "How have you helped me?" he asked, looking back up into her eyes, anger flashing across his face.

Kirstin sat back in the back seat of the hire car and looked back out of the window. She considered her answer carefully. This young, fourteen year old boy was scared - she could see that. But it was important that she did not reveal her assignment too early. There were many secrets Ahreed would need to keep for the Australian Secret Intelligence Organisation, some of them stretching back into a history before he was born, others reaching out into the future security of Australia.
"Your School," she began, fixing back on his expectant, deep brown eyes, "It's a special school we sent you to with your father's permission."

Ahreed paused. He wondered about what the woman Kirstin had just said. "What do you mean, my Baba gave the permission?"

Kirstin again thought carefully about her answer to the boy while holding his worried gaze. She did not want to reveal anything about Ahreed's father that perhaps, his father had not explained to him. But at the same time, she needed to win his trust. The government had spent a lot of money helping Ahreed, his father and the rest of Ahreed's family. This long term plan depended heavily on this conversation with Ahreed and what choices he might make in an uncertain future.

Kirstin blinked. "Ahreed, your dad has helped the Australian Government a great deal," she took hold of his hand again, "And we trust your dad so much, it's difficult for me to explain."

Ahreed pulled his hand away and adjusted his posture in the back seat of the car, still propped on the tarmac with the plane visible in the windscreen. He did not quite understand what the woman Kirstin was saying to him.

She looked down, then back up into his eyes again. "We need to stop the killing, Ahreed... you must know what happened in Melbourne a few weeks ago."

"Yes," replied Ahreed, "I saw what happened." He paused again, looking back through the windscreen at the plane. "It was evil, Miss Kirstin."

"Yes," she replied, " It was evil. There were thirty thousand people in that stadium, Ahreed. Over a thousand are dead and nearly three thousand are sick from the gas."

Ahreed looked back at the young woman's eyes. "They were Jihadists from ISIS."

"Yes they were, Ahreed," continued Kirstin, "But would you ever do such a thing like that?"

Ahreed could feel a tear in his eyes, glancing uneasily back out at the plane through the window of the car. He blinked, and two tears ran down either side of his face. "In the name of Allah, Miss Kirstin, in the name of the loving, the merciful, the beautiful Allah, no, I would never do something like that." Ahreed's gaze fixed ahead, as more tears welled in his eyes.

Kirstin looked at the boy as he stared distantly ahead, both admiring and lamenting Ahreed's sentiment. So many of the terrorist fighters had probably felt this way in their youth. So deep was their love and concern for others in their hearts as children. Naturally maturing young boys emerging into manhood, they had stared ahead into a brighter future, faithfully optimistic yet blissfully naive. And yet, as time and maturity washed over them like a warm, Pacific wave on a tropical island paradise, the sting of a hidden creature in the foam had struck: poisoning, frightening, compelling them them to a tragic choice of devastation.

Kirstin noticed the faint whisps of whiskers on Ahreeds upper lip. His toned, brown skin and long eyelashes, wetted (moistened) by the tears of an ancient (a timeless) dilemma. He was a beautiful kid, and since reading his file at her desk a few weeks ago she had wondered many times about his appearance. Seeing him here now in the back of the car at Sydney airport, for the first time, she realised that this was an important moment in the transition process. Kirstin knew her job, knew Ahreed's history and knew the pressure of her assignment. But now that the boy was finally in her hands, she strived to find the right words. He was just a child.

She glanced up at the rear vision mirror and, seeing (her partner's) Russell's gaze, lifted her hand in a gesture to wait. Looking back at Ahreed she watched as the boy began to sob. She took hold of his hand again and squeezed gently, turning and placing her other hand on his shoulder. "It will be okay, Ahreed. I'm sorry if we frightened you. Don't be afraid." She waited a moment before continuing, "You will be back home tonight, I promise."

Ahreed looked back down into his lap, then glanced out of the side window of the car into the distant horizon of the airport.

"I'm afraid, Ms Kirstin. I'm scared you are going to hurt me." The boy sobbed some more, still staring across the fields of grass and tar into the distance "I don't understand what is happening."

"Look at me, Ahreed," pressed Kirstin suddenly, "Look at me!"

The boy slowly turned back to Kirstin.

"You must trust us, Ahreed," she continued, "We are not the enemy. This is Australia, and you are an Australian. We care about you."

Ahreed looked down, still confused.

Kirstin persisted, "You are special, Ahreed. You are a clever boy. We know you can help us, but you MUST trust us." She watched as the fourteen year old remained motionless, looking down into his lap as if somehow ashamed.

She was concerned about stretching beyond her instructions and giving the boy some assurance. She was not supposed to do that right now. Her brief was to bring Ahreed to Canberra so that the experienced inductors could reveal to Ahreed the purpose of his engagement. She noted a concerned glance from Russell in the front seat, turning his head suddenly in her direction.

"Ahreed," she continued, "We must end the evil... we must stop the killing, and you can help do that."

Ahreed's watery eyes looked up at the young woman. His gaze lingered for several moments, then, he looked back down into his lap.

Kirstin, still holding Ahreed's hand and her other hand on his shoulder, looked up at the man in the driver's seat. She nodded at him.

Russell opened the door of the car.
111.title: Many Secrets...

1111.content:
Ahreed walked over the tarmac to the steps leading to the plane, the man Russell always by his side. As he rose on the stairs he looked back across the airport, across Sydney. He felt unsure that he would ever see the city again.

Inside the plane there were two corridors: the woman Kirstin led Ahreed down the right hand corridor, past a wall and into a seating area. It was very comfortable. The chairs were wide and there was a table between them with drinks and food. Ahreed had only been on a plane once before and it had simply been rows and rows of seats. He had never seen a plane like this.

The man Russell sat down opposite and Kirstin directed Ahreed to his seat, next to her.

Kirstin sat down, watching Ahreed and then glancing up at Russell, his eyes fixed on hers in a way that was a bit disturbing for her. She knew she had already told the boy too much. Russell was her superior and he told Kirstin with his eyes that he was concerned. Kirstin trusted her instincts. She was ASIO's most qualified Middle Eastern cultural specialist.

Ahreed sat back and glanced across the table in between Russell and Kirstin. He was hungry and thirsty, since leaving the King's School at such a time meant he had missed lunch.

"Go ahead," gestured the woman Kirstin, "Have something to eat."

Ahreed stretched out his arm and grabbed one of the rolls on the table between the seats.

Kirstin watched him, wondering about her description of events and whether or not it had impacted on the interview she knew was about to happen in Canberra. The boy needed to be ready for what he was about to face.

Russell leant back in his chair and closed his eyes.

After awhile, Kirstin leaned forward to Ahreed and asked, "Are you still scared of us?"

The boy was drinking a bottle of orange juice, and as Kirstin spoke he pulled it away from his mouth to answer. "I'm scared, yes, Miss Kirstin."

"What is it you are scared of, Ahreed?" Kirstin asked, continuing to move through her required set of conversation points with Ahreed. There was a list of questions she was required to ask the boy before his arrival at ASIO Headquarters in Canberra. She was not sure if Russell was listening in, as he remained silent and motionless with his eyes closed in the seat opposite.

Ahreed held the orange juice bottle in his hand, then answered, "I'm scared I am in some kind of trouble, Ms Kirstin."

"I hope not, Ahreed," replied the young ASIO agent, "But we'll see once we get to Canberra."

Ahreed put down the bottle of orange juice on the table. The plane seemed to be turning and he could feel the floor beneath him tilting. He did not understand what the woman Kirstin had just said to him. 'She hopes not', thought Ahreed, going back over her words in his mind. What would happen to him if he has truly made some terrible mistake?
1111.title: The plane trip to Canberra...

11111.content:
Ahreed sat worried about his fate, locked in this small room with a mirror behind him and one single chair in front of him. The stainless steel table in front of him was also scary, for would his blood be spilled upon it? After a short time the woman Kirstin came into the room. She explained the situation to him, then the man Russell entered the room as well.

Ahreed listened to them both, thought about his sister in Melbourne and his brother at the Kings School in Sydney, wondering what would become of them. He agreed to the terms that ASIO offered him. In return for his help to uncover the Jihadist recruiters, he would be given free University and would be guaranteed of a good job in the government once he had completed his study. These things were everything his Baba had ever wanted for him.

After a couple of hours, Ahreed was transported back to the airport and flown back to Sydney. There was a car waiting to pick him up, which drove him back home.
11111.title: The call of Canberra...

1112.content:
Ahrou noticed that his younger brother was not on the bus to the station. The noise of his friends and the background in the packed bus dimmed as he wondered about Ahreed.

Walking home from the station, Ahrou began to feel a bit confused. Should he be more concerned about his brother? Or about Mr Bhaduri's concern for Ahreed? It was indeed very strange that Ahreed had disappeared from school - Ahrou knew that Ahreed had caught the morning bus. Surely his brother would have mentioned to him on the walk to the station in the morning, if he was not catching the afternoon bus with his older brother.

This was typical of Ahreed. He did not understand his responsibilities like he should. He was a bad Muslim, Ahrou thought as he trudged along the street.

Once home, Ahrou went up to his room and started his computer. There were some new videos he had heard about that he wanted to watch immediately.

Ahreed adjusted his posture in the back seat of the car, reaching into his pocket for his own phone. He did not trust the young woman. He felt he could not even trust that 'Kirstin' was her real name.

The phone only rang once when his Baba suddenly answered, "Ahreed? Is that you??" Ahreed could hear tension in his voice.

"Yes, Baba.. - " Ahreed was unsure what he should say to his dad.

"Ahreed, are you ok? Tell me you ok." Baba called over the headset, sounding a bit panicked.

"Yes Baba, but I'm scared, Babi," tears welling up in his eyes, "I want to come home..."

"You will, you will Ahree," reassured Baba, "I should see you tonight, it all will be ok."

Ahreed was sobbing, "But why, Baba? Why is this? I'm scared they're going to hurt me, Baba.."

Akram Hussein, 67, was worried about his youngest child and knew he had to explain. He'd always known ASIO was coming for Ahreed because the Australian Government had been supporting his whole family since its arrival in Sydney nine years ago. ASIO had also alerted him of their plan to move Ahreed to a new school in this year, but Akram had expected it would be at the end of the year. He assumed the speeding up of the process was because of the Melbourne terror alert he had heard about. Everyone was on edge after the Australian Prime Minister's emergency announcement to the nation about a possible gas attack in a Melbourne sports stadium.

His daughter Noora was also studying at Melbourne University while Ahreed and his older brother, Ahrou were attending the Kings School, Sydney's most prestigious secondary college. Noora was doing medicine and Akram and both of his sons, Ahreed and Ahrou were very proud of her.

Akram could not be certain if his daughter would have done so well if not for the Australian Security Services. Because of his previous work with the Iranian Government's nuclear program, Akram and his family were welcomed as refugees, but at a cost. One of his beloved children should give back and Ahreed, even brighter than his older sister, had been chosen before the boy had started high school. He was to do two years at the Kings School, then move to Alnoori Muslim School. If successful at this next process Ahreed was facing right now, he was to become a sleeper cell embedded in the radical Muslim community by ASIO. They were especially interested in the radicalization of young teenaged boys.

The aging engineer had already faced his own struggles in Australia. The fear of detection as an agent by others in the Muslim community, the regular moving of their home for security reasons, the loss of his beloved wife. Having no mother from four years of age, Ahreed too, had suffered. Akram explained all of this to Ahreed for what seemed like hours, though it was really only a precious few minutes. The phone call suddenly ended.

Ahreed frantically lifted up the phone, immediately suspicious that the ASIO people had done something to the end the call. But it was just a flat battery. Agreed had seen the woman Kirstin using the phone: she must have known the battery was almost flat.




Mr Bhaduri looked across his maths class at the Kings School. Ahreed's desk was empty and he'd heard nothing about why. Slightly annerved, he continued to walk up and down the aisles as the rest of his students worked away at the test. Ahreed was a special student and Mr Bhaduri had often wondered about the boy's background, potential and the possible disturbance of losing his mother at such a young age. There could very well be the spark in that boy and the maths teacher had plans for him.

The two Hussein brothers were rare Muslims at the leading Sydney school. Bhaduri had waited some years for this type of student and soon, he would be sure of their safety. Ahrou Hussein was doing very well but the maths teacher was suspicious of the boys' origins. Their baba being a truck driver and a single parent, how on earth could the family pay such high prices for education? One of Bhaduri's Syrian friends had also noticed the peculiar name of Ahrou, not being familiar with it as a Syrian name, plus the boy's accent and speaking style. Bhaduri's friend was even more perplexed when told Ahreed's name which was, again, not familiar in Syria. Yet according the student files of the boys, they were Syrian.
112.title: Many Questions...

1121.content:
Still, Ahreed was confused. He was definitely in some kind of detention, controlled by Australia's secret service. He was scared, his heart pounding from the moment he left the King's School in Sydney. It was a constant stress being pressed on him. There must have been something he had done wrong. Perhaps someone he knew was connected with the sports stadium terror threat he had seen in the news.

Ahreed's Baba had told him many things but they simply swirled around in Ahreed's head. This room was confinement: he was a prisoner. It was true, what he had heard, that the Australian government hated Muslims, was watching them and would punish them for the sins of a few crazies. A large mirror behind him - he knew they were watching him through the mirror - a TV camera above his head looking down at him - so they could see his face - only one chair in front of him, so his interview would be 1 on 1.

After what seemed like hours to Ahreed, the door of the room swung open and the young woman Kirstin came in, sitting down in the one chair without looking at Ahreed. She flipped pages in a file and read, flipped and read, looked up at Ahreed now and again, then back down and flipped, and read.

Finally she spoke, "So you wouldn't be a part of a terrorist act in Australia because you love Allah, is that right? Ahreed?"

Ahreed sat upright in his seat, shocked by the sudden aggression in the woman Kirstin. "No!" Ahreed insisted, "I would never be a part of an evil plan to kill people!"

Kirstin looked back down at her notes, folding her arms on the stainless steel desk. The light directly above her created a deep shadow over her face. "Ahreed," she began, pointing at a place on the page in front of her, "I have heard that promise before, then seen the boy catch a plane to Pakistan for the sole purpose of joining ISIS less than two weeks later."

Ahreed felt he was under attack. The woman definitely believed that Ahreed was involved in the stadium terror crisis. "I know nothing about the stadiums," Ahreed blurted out, "And I would NEVER hurt Australia!"

The woman kept looking down at her notes. She was not moved at all by Ahreed's passionate protest. After several moments, she finally asked, "So who mentioned stadiums to you?"

Ahreed's eyes flashed from one side of the table to the other, realising he had made a terrible mistake by mentioning the stadium threat. "My Baba talked to me about this - that it would cause a lot of trouble with our community."

Kirstin looked up into the boy's deep brown eyes. "What does your Baba have to do with the stadium bombing?"

Ahreed felt her eyes tear through his brain, throwing snippets of knowledge into a whirlwind of his mind. There was anger, after years of being afraid just because he was a Muslim being bullied and made fun of at school. There was anger, primal anger, because of the attack on his Baba. He KNEW that Baba was loyal to Australia. He KNEW his Baba was supporting him. There was no way Baba would ever abandon him.

The boy's eyes alighted back at Kirstin's stare, firing back with certainty and faith, stating, "My Baba would never hurt any soul. He came to Australia to be free of this."

"So you want to be free, do you?" fired back Kirstin.

"Australia is a free country - you cannot do this to me!" protested Ahreed.

Kirstin glanced down at her notes then back up at the fiery boy's eyes, "It's free for the right people, Ahreed. But are YOU one of the right people?"

"Yes!!" Ahreed gasped out. He breathed heavily, almost panting like a dog. "Yes I am an Australian, and I have done nothing against my country."

Kirstin looked to the bottom of the sheet in front of her. That was the end of the required questions for Ahreed. It was now time for Russell to speak to the boy and complete the assignment.
1121.title: The Canberra interview: Ahreed faces ASIO

11211.content:
"Ahreed, hi," the man Russell held out his hand to Ahreed.

Ahreed stood and lifted his arm slowly, shaking Russell's outstretched hand, shaking. Ahreed sat back down in his seat.

"Look, I know all of this is difficult," the man began, "But it will all make sense in the end." He kept his eyes fixed on Ahreed's as he sat down in the other chair.

The boy looked back into his lap, the trails of tears in his eyes still visible after Kirstin's interview. "What do you want me for?" asked Ahreed quietly, still looking down.

Russell moved in his seat, thinking how he could connect now that the boy seemed ashamed of himself. "Ahreed, we need your help."

Ahreed paused for a moment, then looked up at the man Russell. "Then why do you treat me like this?" he asked.

Russell shuffled about again, his broad shoulders and large body leaning over the stainless steel desk. There was silence again. He waited a moment before speaking. "I promise you, in a few hours you will be back with your Baba."

"How can I trust you?" asked the fourteen year old boy.

"Because we trust YOU," continued Russell, "YOU are our main concern."

Ahreed was unsure. "Why me?" he inquired of his more friendly interrogator, persisting at looking down.

Russell looked down too. It was clear the boy was not going to look in his eyes. "Because you," he paused, "Because you are not just an Australian - you are a special Australian."

"This is how you treat someone special?" asked Ahreed, still looking down in his lap.

"You will understand, Ahreed," persisted Russell, "You will get a picture of things like no one else before has had."

Ahreed looked up at the man Russell. His eyes were fixed on Ahreed's and it was clear the man was watching Ahreed's every movement. "What kind of picture is that?" the boy recounted.

"A picture of the world, Ahreed," began Russell, "A picture of the people smuggling, the human trafficking, the drug trade, the systems these people use to convince young boys like you that their world is exciting, compelling, that they must come over and fight the Jihad.."

Ahreed looked down again.

Russell continued, "Ahreed, we need boys like you who can find these people." But the boy kept looking down. Russell persisted, "We need boys your age who we can trust."

Ahreed suddenly looked up again at the man, Russell. "How do you expect me to trust you?" Ahreed asked. "Are you hurting my Baba?"

Russell looked down and read his notes for the first time. He looked back up at Ahreed, watching him across the table. "Because your Baba knows what we are doing and wants you to help us."

Ahreed looked down. The thought of his Baba caused tears again in his eyes. "When can I talk with Baba next?" he asked, beginning to sob again.

Russell looked back down at his notes on the table, seeming frustrated. "I told you, Ahreed, you will see him tonight, after our interview."
11211.title: Russell's interview of Ahreed at ASIO:

112111.content:
As Russell left the room, the woman Kirstin entered. Ahreed looked deeper down into his lap, determined not to say any more to her.

"So, Ahreed," she began, looking at the boy, "Your mother was murdered by terrorists.." she trailed off, expectantly.

Ahreed pretended he did not hear the question.

"That must have been difficult for you, Ahreed," Kirstin continued, "It must have made you angry."

The boy kept looking down, freezing his body and not moving at all.

Kirstin persisted with her line of questions. "So your Baba must be angry too, is that right?"

Ahreed wavered in his chair, becoming more and more angry. He wanted to yell at the woman, Kirstin. Instead he just kept ignoring her.

"And your Baba, a mister Akram Hussein, organized the bombing in Melbourne?" Kirstin darted at the boy.

Ahreed looked up at the woman suddenly, anger welling in his tears. His lower face shivering, he answered, "My Baba told me those people were EVIL!" he yelled. "MY BABA SAID, if you ever do anything like this, Ahreed, I will forget you. My Baba said to me, this action will cause all Muslims to be treated badly in Australia, like you are treating ME NOW!" He held the woman's stare for a moment, then looked back down, panting.

Kirstin relaxed and turned over to the next page in her notes. "So you don't know about your father's involvement in the terror attack at the stadium in Melbourne?" she again looked at the boy, awaiting his gaze.

Ahreed lost control. He did not know how to listen or to speak, but started rambling, "My Baba is a good Australian - he told me this country is good and that he came here to protect me and my brother and my sister." Ahreed's voice began to crackle and break as he went on, "My Baba says the government is good, and that my sister will be a doctor one day because of this government.... but why why does this government bring me here? Why do you torture me??" he finished, still panting, now almost hysterical.

Kirstin scribbled a note or two onto the page she was reading. She paused, looked up at Ahreed, his eyes aflamed with anger, staring at her. "You call this torture, Ahreed?"

The boy looked away to the side. He glanced around the room, then back into his lap.

Kirstin placed her notes down on the stainless steel desk and leant forward, pointing her pen across at Ahreed's face, "You don't even know what torture is, young man." She looked back down at her notes.

Ahreed was still panting with rage and fear. He kept looking down. He felt he was in prison, being persecuted by a government who hated Muslims like him. This woman was twisting his words, confusing him. He was afraid to say anything more, but uncontrollably blurted, "Torture is taking me away from home - you have taken me against my will!"

Kirstin held the boy's gaze, and speaking quietly she said, "No, Ahreed, I'm just doing my job. We must question you."

The boy snapped his gaze back down into his hands, fidgeting in his lap. He could never believe that his Baba was responsible for the Melbourne terror threat. It simply was not possible to him. But he could not remember any mention of Melbourne in the news reports he had read and seen on TV. His sister was living in Melbourne...but he could not imagine her involved.

Agreed could feel himself becoming more conflicted and confused. He dared not mention his sister. He thought for a moment. "I thought the terror threat was in Sydney."

Kirstin flicked back to her previous pages and read, then glanced up at Ahreed briefly and back down at her notes. "We know your sister is living in Melbourne, Ahreed." She looked back up at the fourteen year old to see his reaction. His tears were dripping from his chin.

"I only know what I see in the news. I thought it was about Sydney and... I know my sister." Ahreed began gasp, sobbing uncontrollably. He looked up at the woman and yelled, "I KNOW SHE WOULD NOT DO SUCH A THING!"

Kirstin looked down at her notes again. "Did you think you could hide her from us?"

Ahreed was straining the catch his breath. "I.... I just want to protect her. I know nothing about Melbourne, it, it... was not in the news!"

Kirstin pressed further, "What kind of torture are were you expecting from us, Ahreed?"

He began to imagine his worst thoughts of what torture meant. He thought about beheading, the sound of a cow as the knife was dragged across its neck. He thought about being shot in a firing squad. He thought about his Baba, yelling at him with a knife in his hand. For a brief moment, he saw a vision of his mother, blood all over her dress, lying on the ground reaching out to him.

Kirstin watched the boy's face. Ahreed was very distressed - she could see that. She waited, watching the tears run down his brown cheeks.

Ahreed looked from side to side. He shook his head, took a breath, then pointed his finger onto the stainless steel table in front of him. "This is torture, Miss Kirstin..." he began, "This is pain. I do not know the answers to your questions."

Kirstin glanced back down at her notes acting casually, flipping the page. But she took a deep breath, beginning to feel for the boy. "Okay, Ahreed, but I need to know what you think we are going to do to you?"

Ahreed paused. He looked up at the woman, Kirstin. He looked around the room again. He looked back at her. She looked young, dark hair and flashing eyes. Her face seemed hard, looking into his eyes. But there was something else. There was something behind her brown eyes and skin, a closeness he had not felt before.

"I do not know, Miss Kirstin," answered Ahreed, glancing down then back up at the young woman. "I cannot imagine."

Suddenly the door opened and the man, Russell entered the room. Kirstin stood up and the two gestured at their notes as Russell sat down. Kirstin closed the door, but remained at the side of the table.

"We are very sorry to put you through this, Ahreed," began Russell, "But it was necessary for us to ask you these things before we move to the next stage."

Ahreed glanced between the two of them. "What do you mean, the next stage?" he asked.

"Your new family, Ahreed," continued Russell. "We have a new Baba for you back in Sydney."

Ahreed was suddenly distressed again, "But my Baba..."

Kirstin interrupted Ahreed, "Your Baba will always be there, Ahreed. We will not take him away from you."

Russell, picking up the conversation added,"We need you to come and work for us. Your dad already works for us and we need you to become a new source of information."

Ahreed was calming down, but still confused. "What information do you want from me? I know nothing."

Kirstin spoke in reply, "But you do, Ahreed. You know many things. Once you are trained by your teacher, you will understand many more things."

"Who is my teacher?" the boy replied.

"His name is Esfir, and he is from Iran, just like your Baba is..." added Russell. "He will guide you, but you need to pretend to be his son."

Ahreed was still confused. "But my Baba, Ahrou my brother, my sister and me.... we are from Syria?" he asked.

Kirstin moved over to the steel desk and leant down to Ahreed. "Your Baba will always be your Baba, Ahreed. You will see him, talk with him, spend time with him. We will make sure of that. All of your family will be safe, but no, you did not come from Syria. You came from Iran."

Slowly, Ahreed began to calm down. So much had happened today, and in a few hours it seemed like his whole life had changed. Yet somehow, he had always known deep down that he was going to be connected with the troubles of the Australian Muslims. It was as though his Baba had prepared him. He realized that the sudden departure of his sister to Melbourne, the beginning of his high school at the King's School in Sydney, all of it was connected.

"We're sorry, Ahreed," started Kirstin, "But we had to ask you certain questions."

Russell added, "And I was the good cop, while Kirstin had to be the bad cop, Ahreed...that's why she seemed so nasty." Russell gestured with his hand towards the notes on the table in front of him, "It was the procedure we had to follow."

Ahreed could feel his heart slowing down. For the first time since this afternoon, he was calm again. Still, he was uncertain what all of this meant.
112111.title: Kirstin returns to Ahreed...

1121111.content:
Esfir Haidi was also from Iran and had been an ASIO operative for some years. He remembered well the evacuation of Akram Hussein and his family, being a huge success for the Australians at the time. Akram had been a key engineer in the design and process of achieving nuclear capability under the recent Iranian regime.

Esfir was previously a part of the old regime's intelligence service and had defected to Australia quietly many years ago. At that time he could foresee the fall of the government in Iran and the introduction of Sharia Law. As a modern, well educated man, Esfir knew that the trends of the western world would be of little interest to the old social system restored in his homeland. Esfir realized at that time there was no point remaining in Iran.

His departure left behind his wife and two beloved children, Javeed and Koosha. Even after so many years, he still didn't know their fate. He hoped deep down that one day, as part of his work for the Australian Secret Intelligence Organization, he would learn what happened to them.

The call on his ASIO phone message system surprised him, but also buoyed his hopes for another assignment in the Middle East. It was an advice that his new teenage son, Ahreed, was in Canberra and being prepared for activation as an anti-terrorist informer. Of course, this was not one of his real sons. It was simply the creation of a family unit, for undetected travel into the world of the human traffickers at the edge of the Mediterranean Sea.

Esfir went back to his study and picked up the file on the boy. No mother, his father another operative like Esfir, the boy's brother mixed up with radicals in the community. It seemed to Esfir that ASIO had the right pick. But how would the plan work on the ground, when they were placed in Libya?

He made a brief call to his housekeeper. He needed a room to be prepared for the boy. It was important that Esfir establish a good relationship with the fourteen year old Ahreed, so that outsiders would not notice that the two of them were a false creation of ASIO. This was just as important in Sydney as it was in Pakistan, or Libya, or in Egypt. He hoped Ahreed's language skills were up to scratch in Arabic.

All of these locations were possible 'drop points' for the pair, as they collected and reviewed information about the money making schemes of ISIS. His ASIO assignment for most of the current year had been about the financing of the 'Hundred Year War'. He wondered how long it would take the boy to be inducted into ASIO and sent to his house to live.

Esfir had his own system of training prepared for this Ahreed boy, and he needed time to ensure the kid was ready for deployment in the Middle East. He looked down again through his notes...
1121111.title: Ahreed's new Baba is contacted...

11211111.content:
Esfir was thinking about the complexities of training the boy and somehow ensuring his safety. The boy was a very important asset for the Australian Secret Intelligence Organisation. Esfir's phone suddenly rang again. Esfir answered immediately.

"It's 115 point 14, can you respond?" asked the voice.

"Yes Russ, " replied Esfir, "I can respond with diligence."

"Ok," continued Russell on the end of the line, "The boy is being airlifted directly to you immediately."

Esfir was confused. "What about his induction?" he asked.

There was some hesitation on the phone line, "It's been given to you to look after," replied Russell, sounding frustrated.

"That is a sudden change in plan, yes?" asked Esfir, "And how does the boy feel about this?"

There was more hesitation. "He doesn't know yet," Russ replied.

Esfir paused. This was a very big responsibility he was about to take on. Russell was asking him to both induct the 14 year old boy plus give him cover in the local community in Sydney. "Alright," he agreed, "But this is a lot of work - you know this?"

"Yeah, yeah..." continued Russ, "We know it's a big ask, Esfir. But there's orders from above about rapid deployment of the asset."

"Asset?" questioned Esfir, "He is a fourteen year old boy!" Esfir was not really upset, but he felt he should show some concern while agreeing to the proposal. "What about the family in Melbourne - can't they take him? There are two operatives, husband and wife to look after the child?"

"That remains an option, one-nine." was the reply on the phone.

"And does this child, Arghreed, look like me? You think us Muslims all look the same?"

There was a pause on the phone. "He has to stay in Sydney and move to the 'mozzie' school, Esfir.... we need to find leads into the Melbourne bombing threat quickly and we suspect it came from Sydney."

Esfir paused again. "I suppose so..." he continued, slowly, "I will do this for our organisation, agent one-four."

Russell, still at the Canberra headquarters of ASIO, breathed a sigh of relief. "We'll send him directly, by chopper."

Esfir became falsely upset again: "Why you send chopper to my house at night - the neighbours wonder who I am??"

Russell was expecting some resistance. "We need to get him started straight away, one-nine," he replied officially, "He flies out in five days."

Esfir was shocked. Five days? How on earth could he prepare a 14 year old boy for espionage in five days? Anyway, he had already agreed to the assignment, according to the code of ASIO.

Russell was waiting on the line. "Esfir?" he called.

"Yes, yes..." Esfir replied, "I will take the boy tonight and begin immediately - fly out in five days."

"Confirmed, one-one-five, one-nine." Russell terminated the call.

At ASIO in Canberra, Russell turned and looked at the boy through the mirror glass and sighed. He and Kirstin had just broken a promise, to return Ahreed to his family immediately.
11211111.title: Suddenly, another phone call...

choices: Ahreed is stranded... (cut off from his Baba)
112111111.content:
As Ahreed stepped out of the car onto the tarmac at Canberra airport, he could only see a black helicopter.

"Have you ever flown in a chopper, Ahreed?" asked Kirstin.

"No," replied the boy, "We are going back to Sydney now, yes?" he asked.

"Choppers are much quicker, " continued Kirstin, "Hop in and I will explain."

Ahreed turned and started walking toward the chopper as its blades began to turn slowly. There was a deep, low drone of a sound with a high pitched noise as the blades swung over his head. He ducked. He felt Kirstin's hand on his shoulder as he approached the sliding door of the helicopter.

In the air, flying over the countryside, Ahreed stared out across the coloured sky. Soon it would be sunset. "How long will it take to get back to Sydney in the chopper, Ms Kirstin?" he asked through the headset.

"Well, Ahreed, " she answered, "We're stopping on the way to meet someone important. I suppose it would take another hour or so to get to Sydney from there?" She turned and looked at the boy, as though being sincere. Kirstin knew the boy would not be returning home that night. She knew he would feel betrayed eventually.

As the dark coloured chopper descended onto the football field near to Esfir's home at the secret location, Ahreed stretched to look out of the window. He could see a man standing there on the rugby field, surrounded by Australian bush.

As the chopper touched down on the ground, Kirstin and Russell hopped out and Ahreed followed. His hand on Ahreed's head, Russell jogged alongside the teenager as he moved out from beneath the spinning blades of the helicopter.

Kirstin ran over to the man waiting on the ground, shook his hand, then turned to Ahreed with a gesture. The man came over. "Don't try to talk!" he yelled, the noise of the chopper still spinning and the smell of kerosene filling the air. He put his arm over Ahreed's shoulder and directed him away to the edge of the football field. The woman Kirstin and the man Russell then got back into the helicopter and within seconds, it lifted off the ground and up into the air, its flashing lights becoming smaller as it rapidly fled into the night sky.

The overwhelming noise faded away and Esfir directed the boy onto a track leading into the bush. "Everything will be alright," he assured the youth, "I know your Baba."

Ahreed was worried about the disappearance of the chopper. How would he get home to Sydney tonight if the chopper had gone? The sun was setting and he noticed that the place he was in was very beautiful. He glanced around at the coloured sky and the graphic mountain outline in the distance. The air was now filled with the music of a thousand birds, its crisp, fresh scent making him a little dizzy.
112111111.title: time to fly again...

1121111111.content:
Esfir kept looking back at Ahreed's face. The boy was obviously panicked by the departure of the helicopter. Esfir tightened his grip around the boy's shoulder.

Entering Esfir's house in the Australian bush, Ahreed was taken by its beauty. It was a sprawling, open-plan house with large spaces and staircases rising and descending all around him as he entered. Esfir went up to the kitchen and started the jug to make cups of tea. He glanced up and noticed the sun setting in the western sky out of the window of his mountain side house.

"Ahreed," he began, "You are in a secret place."

The boy stopped in the middle of the spacious, mid-level living area. He was astounded at what he saw. There was a fire burning, but the floor was white. There were beautiful pieces of artwork hanging on the wall and a lovely, dark red leather couch stretched across the room. The white floor and the fire together seemed quite strange to Ahreed. He turned back to the man up on the higher level, but quite close to him. "Where am I?" he asked slowly.

Esfir looked down at the bubbling window of the jug as it began to boil. "You are at home, Ahreed, you are now my son."

Ahreed could feel his heart start to pound inside his chest. Where was his Baba? Where was his Dad?

Esfir could see that the boy was unsettled. "Sit down, Ahreed, you are in my house now."

The young boy didn't move, instead looking back up at Esfir. "What do you mean that you are my Baba?" he asked, a tear welling up around his eyes.

"Your Baba is safe, Ahreed, " said Esfir quickly, "He is waiting for you and will see you soon."

"But when will I be home again??" protested Ahreed.

Esfir looked down to the floor. Slowly he said, "You are home, now, Ahreed. You must call ME Baba now."

"But my REAL Baba, " called out Ahreed, crying openly, " When will I see him again? Kirstin and Russell said he would be here!!"

The older man looked at the face of the boy and felt a pang in his heart. Such a betrayal of a young one by ASIO made his urgent task more difficult.
1121111111.title: Ahreed is stranded... (cut off from his Baba)

11211111111.content:
"It is the old way, Arghreed," began Esfir, slipping back to his natural accent, "That the boy is taken from his family by an uncle, who teaches him a trade."

Ahreed's sobbing slowed. His tear streamed face lingered on the eyes of Esfir. He watched as the older man looked out to the western windows of the bright, palatial living room. The reds and oranges of the sunset glimmered in his eyes. Ahreed was mesmerized.

"But as always, first, we pray." Esfir walked over to a cupboard under one of the staircases and opened its elaborately decorated panel. He unhooked two mats, closed the cupboard and placed them both carefully on the floor, aligning to the sunset.

Ahreed felt himself slowly walking towards the mats, hearing the call to prayer ring out in his ears several seconds before Esfir turned on the actual sound of the call to prayer on the iPod dock. The perfect light streamed onto the open, paved slate floor on the other side of the room. It was as though Ahreed was stepping back in time.

"Come, Arghree," gestured Esfir warmly, "This is your home, and this is where we pray."




After prayers Ahreed felt relieved. It seemed as if something was normal again. Esfir seemed to be talking more and more Arabic and less English as the evening went on. They talked into the night about history, religion, business and crime.

Although heavily weighed down with the pressure of his assignment, Esfir had moments when he noticed the incredible intelligence of the boy. He also seemed a gentle soul, but this could be a devastating weakness for a new operative. There was hardening that needed to be done, yet Esfir also wondered if the deep desire for peace and to end the killing was perhaps necessary. It meant so much to Ahreed that people stop fighting and dying. It had really troubled the boy through the years, Esfir thought.

"Do you think of your mother often?" asked Esfir, at a specially chosen moment.

"Yes, I wonder about her a lot," replied the boy. "I still see her face sometimes, hear different music and remember an aroma that always seemed to linger in the air when I was with her."

Esfir diverted the sensitive question away and began to explain to Ahreed about the ANZACS - The Australian and New Zealand Army Corps. The legend of the ANZACS was central to the military belief system of all Australians. It was important that Ahreed understood the relationship between the English and Arab cultures and its recent history.

Ahreed was fascinated with the attack on Turkey in World War One. "But the Turkish Moslems won, yes?" he asked Esfir.

"Do not use that word, Argreed. You should say, 'muss-lim', not 'mozz-lem', and yes, the Turks did win, Ahreed. But you must understand, they were defending their home lands, their families, their cities. The Australian soldiers were only there - many of them - because they were young and seeking adventure."

Ahreed thought for a moment, the odd snap of the open fire breaking the pause late in the night. "Why would a soldier go to war, just for adventure?"

Esfir was taken aback by Ahreed's thoughtful summary of the conversation. "Because they were YOUNG, Ahreed," pressed Esfir, "And that is why they follow their older brothers, their cousins and all of the other men in the town, joining the great army to fight in far away lands. They did not want to be left behind. Boys will follow men, to learn manhood. And younger boys might call them cowards if they remain and are suddenly the eldest."

"They were not as young as me," mumbled Ahreed.

"Yes, YES," protested Esfir, "Most of them were over eighteen, but some of them WERE like you, pretending to be older. In Syria there are many hundreds - maybe thousands of child soldiers, just like you."

"Is that what you want me for, to be a soldier?" asked Ahreed.

Esfir was confounded by the boy's insight and directness. "No, Arghreed, not a soldier. You are now an operative, working for the Australian Government. They will keep educating you, and put money aside for you, so long as you remain loyal to your new country. And that is why you must understand how sacred the ANZAC spirit is to this people."

Ahreed thought again. "So I will become an ANZAC, or go back to school?"

"Perhaps you will spend time at a school, but you will be working for ASIO," replied Esfir. "For now we use the old way for your education, the way of the old country. I become your teacher, the uncle who shows you the trade. You can never be an ANZAC, Arghreed, for they are the legends of battles past, teaching us in dreams at night when we sleep. You can only live up to their honour and make your new country proud."

Ahreed sank further back into the soft, leather couch in front of the fire. It was late into the night and he was very tired.

Esfir stared into the flames of the fire, thinking. It was another good question the boy had asked, about going to school or going to war. ASIO had confused Esfir by stating that Ahreed was to change schools, yet he was to fly out in just a few days.

Finally, Esfir said, "And the tools of the trade we must teach you to use." Esfir supposed that these tools included spying on classmates, as well as shooting guns.

After another long pause, he continued to question Ahreed about his feelings for his mother.

"Did your father tell you what happened to her?"

Ahreed hesitated. "Yes, he said she got sick in the refugee camp in Syria and didn't make it."

Esfir looked down at the slate floor suddenly. "I see, and you see too, I hope, that many horrors are hidden from the children, Arghree?"

"What are you saying about my mother?" replied Ahreed in Arabic, sitting forward on the couch suddenly, "Where did she die?"

The older man quickly waved his arm back and forth in front of his shirt, "No, no, Arghree, you are misunderstanding me: this is an ancient Arab saying, 'Many horrors are hidden from the children'. It means that children should stay children." Esfir was impressed the boy used Arabic to protest, but he also noticed that Ahreed's accent was a bit of a concern. One could tell it was Iranian to a trained ear.

The boy slumped back in his chair and stared straight ahead. He yawned hard. It was late and it had been a very long and scary day.
11211111111.title: The old way ...

112111111111.content:
The two only slept a few hours before Esfir stirred Ahreed for morning prayer. The light in the huge room was different now, in the morning. Ahreed had fallen asleep on a sprawling, soft leather couch in front of the fire, which was still warming the room.

After prayers Esfir took him to another room, downstairs under the house. Ahreed was shocked. He looked at the cabinets, glass doors and shelves. There were drawers with numbers too. Completely surrounding the boy was his worst fear of all: guns.

Esfir could see the distress on the boy's face. "It is also the old way to know defence." stated Esfir. "If a man is pointing a gun at me and you can see another gun, would you let that man shoot me, Arghree?"

Ahreed felt dizzy. He was confused and frightened, becoming pale.

"These are machines, Arghreed, tools of our trade."

Ahreed sat down on the second bottom step, feeling slightly ill in the stomach. He looked down at the floor, then back up at the rows and rows of weapons around the walls.

"You must learn," continued Esfir,"How to care for them, hold them, load them, and when to use them. You must also learn when to avoid using them and pretend you know nothing about them."

Ahreed began to focus. Esfir diverted back into the philosophy of ISIS and the promise a one hundred year war. There was a history of weapons and their use, including why they were used. He explained to the boy about the excitement of shooting guns for some people, and the camaraderie of an army. Its strength being based on its capacity to do what needed to be done: if one soldier was defeated, another takes his place.

"It is always better to avoid using guns if possible, and not to let others know your capability. Once you can hold and use some of these guns, anyone watching from a distance will know you have been trained.You must not reveal to anyone that you are trained until absolutely necessary, Arghreed." Esfir grabbed an M1 from the wall and turned to Ahreed.

The boy stood up slowly, walking towards Esfir. He held out his hands. As he took the weight of the metal he was shocked how heavy it was. Its cold body sent a chill up Ahree's spine. "Is it loaded?" he asked timidly, his legs beginning to shake.

"No, no, Arghree, it's not loaded. I will teach you how to hold it first before we start with fake bullets." Esfir stepped forward and pointed to the side of the gun and began explaining to Ahreed the functions, aiming and loading mechanisms. Gradually, Ahreed tuned in, absorbing all of the technicalities of some weapons he was likely to see in coming days in the Middle East.
112111111111.title: Ahreed's next day ...

1121111111111.content:
Looking down at the small, round white tablet in his hand, Ahreed considered his ISIS Commander's advice: 'This will calm you, down, Ahreed,' he had said, 'And you will fight to win the right to the glory of Islam. And if it is the Will of Allah, you shall sleep with seven virgins at sunset.'

Ahreed wondered if he should take the tablet straight away because he needed calming down. Squatting on the wooden floor of the partially destroyed building in a small village near the Syrian city of Al Bukamal, near the Iraq border, Ahreed was facing his first contact with defending forces near the Iraqi city of Qa'im. In fact, it was Ahreed's first battle with ISIS.

Since the raid at the hotel in the Libyan coastal city of Al Marj several weeks earlier, Ahreed had been siphoned across the borders of Egypt and Jordan and into the south of Syria. He often wondered what had happened to Esfir. The last time Ahreed saw his new Baba, Esfir was kneeling on the ground outside the hotel with his hands on his head, a jihadist pointing a gun at his face.

Since that horrific nightmare, there was moving, moving, moving all of the time. There had been training and instruction in the principles of jihad along the way, including the bloody slaughter of about a dozen people in a tiny village somewhere between Tirbil in southern Iraq and At Tanf over the border in Syria. So far as Ahreed could comprehend, the slaughter was simply an exercise and the people who died mere 'crash-test dummies', for that is how they were described in Arabic by his ISIS leaders. Their mocking and laughter, bloodthirsty drunken talk around the fires at night, frequently kept the young recruits awake.

This tablet in Ahreed's hand, if it could calm him down, would be exactly what he needed. He turned to his fellow freedom fighter sharing his sleeping sack on the floor next to him.

"Should I take this now, or in the morning, Ahmed?" asked Ahreed.

"No, no, no, you take it one half hour before the battle my brother, it gives you strength!"

The Australian boy slipped the tablet into the top pocket of his shirt. "I thought it was to calm me down, so the commander told me."

Ahmed sat up from his bedding. "Ahreed it will calm you down, and also make you strong. It is a special weapon of the freedom fighters that they have, but the enemy does not. When you take this, you will understand."

Ahreed sat and then lay down on his side of the sack, exhausted but still terrified and still afraid to sleep. What had happened to Esfir, he wondered. What would happen to him, tomorrow?
1121111111111.title: The bitter pill...

11211111111111.content:
As the troop continued their march the next day, Ahreed wondered about the white tablet in his top pocket. Perhaps it would kill him, or perhaps it could help him. He turned to Hakim, a twelve year old boy marching next to him. "What does the white tablet do to me?" asked Ahreed, in Arabic.

The younger boy kept marching in the troop, not acknowledging Ahreed's question at first. After about ten more steps, he replied, "It makes you stronger in battle, you will understand."

Ahreed didn't think much of the boy's answer. He kept on marching in step with the troop, wondering what the small white tablet in his upper shirt pocket really did. Looking up across the troop, he wondered about the group of boys he had been forced into, realising most of them were younger than him.

"You talk funny," continued the younger boy. He looked across at Ahreed. "Your Arabic is strange."

Ahreed had been warned about his accent by Esfir, and he wondered if his ISIS Commander had noticed his peculiar way of talking. "I am from Australia," he replied to young Hakim as they walked, "My accent is Australian Arabic."

Hakim was shorter than Ahreed. He had no whiskers and a deep, brown face. His eyes were dark and broken, having seen too many things to sparkle like a child's anymore. He had grown up in a war torn Syria and at a young age, watched as his father was beheaded by a jihadi leader. For reasons of sheer survival, he followed every command of his ISIS leader. His father had been a Shi'ite moslem.

The younger boy would do or be whatever he was told without question, so now he was a Sunni.

Ahreed began to feel he was meant to be on this trail. He was afraid of what was ahead, but worried about the fate of his fellow child soldiers. Most of them were so young, yet so hardened. They knew more about the trail ahead than him, but little about being children.

Ahreed knew of a different world, a different life growing up in Australia. There was plenty of food, a warm bed every night, fun and friends and games and school. There were very few dangers for a child in Sydney: no fear of your home being bombed in the night, nor terror at the appearance of an aircraft in the sky. There was abundant opportunity, friendly people everywhere and a loving family. Though for Ahreed, there had always been just one thing missing, his mother.

Suddenly, he felt a deep, protective instinct for the boys marching around him. He had been so young when his mother was lost, but he remembered her arm around him, the tight grasp of her hand and the warmth of her embrace. He felt he would never have survived without her. But these boys, they had no mother. What did they have to protect them?

The Commander suddenly raised his hand and the boys ducked down to the ground. Ahreed ducked down with them. The Commander looked over his shoulder and gestured to the troop, two young boys running out and settling at his feet, trained to obey.

After looking carefully ahead, the Commander leant over and whispered to the two boys then gestured back towards the rest of the troop. The boys - no older than eleven or twelve - then scurried back to the rest of the assembly of children and began briefing them on the Commander's plan.

Ahead there was a small village. Two older boys would follow the Commander forward towards the village, while the remaining troops would divide into two groups, one flanking the left side, the other the right. Hakim headed to the right while Ahreed followed his comrades to the left, keeping low as he scurried across the sand. From a rooftop up ahead in the village, there was a sudden burst of gunfire. It was a thunderstorm of noise, echoes and confusion followed by dull thuds in the ground all around them.

Ahreed glanced across to Hakim in the other group and watched, in slow motion, as a dull thud struck the body of Hakim. The little boy was thrown back into the air, a spatter of blood flying out over his head, then his limp body fell to the ground at the edge of the village.

Boys around Hakim scambled to take cover as the bullets continued. None of them looked back at Hakim, writhing with pain on the sand as the hot lead sizzled his chest. They just kept moving forward, towards the village.

Ahreed felt a pang of anger in his heart like he had never felt before. He could also feel the tension in his comrades on the left flank: they too were angry about the loss of one of their troop. He noticed some of the boys in front reaching into their pockets and slapping their face. Ahreed reached into his top pocket and fumbled for the white tablet. Feeling it and grasping it, he grabbed desperately and pulled it out, slapping it into his mouth, remembering what Hakim had told him about the white tablet.

The troop paused for about fifteen minutes. Ahreed began to feel a bit dizzy, like he was separating from his body. Then suddenly, the Commander called out in Arabic, "Charge!" and the boys ran out, many of them seemingly running in slow motion to Ahreed.

He stood up, his AK-47 cocked and his finger against the metal trigger, pounding his feet towards the main track through the village. In the corner of his eye, Ahreed noticed a face behind a fence. Ahreed turned, aimed and fired while still running.There was a thud and a splatter of blood in the distance. He didn't know or care anymore, who the face belonged to, adult or child.

Ahreed felt again the same pang of anger he felt a short time ago when he saw Hakim shot. A few seconds seemed like minutes. He also felt the tears. He glanced back. Hakim was no longer moving.

All around Ahreed were faces appearing from behind barriers: he turned to each of them and squeezed his trigger and they flew into the air and down to the ground. He kept following his troop forward. Then there was desert, no town left. He turned and looked back. He could see his Commander standing in the middle of the main street of the village. There was a gathering of his comrades. The Commander was looking directly over at him.

Ahreed marched back towards the middle of the village, his Commander turning back to the group.

On the ground, crawling in front of the Commander was a woman, shielding her toddler child. In Arabic, the Commander yelled, "Where is the sniper??"

The woman cried and muttered in a Kurdish dialect. The Commander glanced up and again looked directly at Ahreed's eyes, marching towards him, then looked back down at the woman and repeated, "Where is the sniper who shot my soldier of God?"

The woman just sobbed, the tiny child beneath her crying.

The Commander turned to his troop sergeant, a boy only about 13 years old. In Arabic, the Commander ordered the boy, "Shoot her filthy rat's arm, so she can see I must have an answer for the glory of Allah."

The young boy hesitated for a moment, glanced up at the Commander, then awkwardly lifted his heavy, AK-47 and switched it to single shot. He took aim, slowly, then shot at the arm of the infant, missing by just a fraction and sending a splatter of sand in the air. The Kurdish woman screamed and lurched further over the toddler.

The Commander stepped over and kicked the woman down to the ground, then, snatching the heavy weapon away from the young boy, methodically lifted its nozzle, aimed and fired through the child's lower arm. The baby let out an desperate scream, crying more hysterically. The Commander then kicked the frantic, crawling woman again, keeping her away from her screaming baby, its arm shot apart and dripping blood into the sand as it flapped its severed limb helplessly in the air.

The Commander turned to his small sergeant with an expression of disgust on his face. The boy soldier obediently took back his weapon and stepped back, standing at attention and awaiting further instruction.

Ahreed's eyes blurred. He felt a shimmering in his legs. He kept marching towards his Commander. The Commander looked back through the troop at Ahreed's eyes in the distance and glanced down at the weapon pointing at the ground as Ahreed kept marching closer towards him.

The Commander unclipped his handgun from its holster, clicked its safety switch as he drew, then pointed it directly at the baby and fired. The impact pushed the tiny child back in the sand, the mother wailing in desperate agony. The Commander then turned his handgun on the mother.

Ahreed, still marching back to the middle of the village, misstepped slightly each time a gunshot echoed along the earthen walls of the buildings in the street. The Kurdish woman fell to the ground, instantly lifeless from the Commander's shot to her forehead. Her blood ran down a furrow in the road, mixing with her child's.

Ahreed kept marching towards his Commander.

The adult turned with his hand gun pointed straight down at the ground as Ahreed approached him.
