112111111111111.content:
Ahreed arrived at the gathering, his weapon still pointing down to the ground. The mingled blood of the mother and child dribbled through the sand to the edge of his boot. "Commander, the north east is clear," he announced.

The commander held Ahreed's gaze as the grown man's thumb restored his handgun to safety mode. Slowly, he lifted the gun and inserted back into its holster. "Very good, Ahreed. You have excelled in your defence of the Almighty. You have risen up to the rank of a Caliphate Warrior. You are now a young lion of Allah!"





Just before dawn of the following day the troop of boy soldiers began to stir. They had eaten well from the stores of the village, while none of its adult occupants seemed to have survived. Many of the younger boys were visibly agitated and several had moved their beds closer to Ahreed by morning.

Ahreed awoke feeling pangs of panic. His memories of the previous day and night seemed clouded, distant and horrific. There were flashbacks to things he had seen: dying comrades, blood spattered sand, the woman and baby and, the thud of that first bullet striking Hakim.

The Commander sat quietly, alone in a smaller room near the larger area where the boys had slept. He listened for movement as he considered the training program for his young warriors, before the company was to continue on its march into the north.

Morning lessons were always dangerous. Without the drug affecting the children, they had only their memories from the day and night before to enrage them. It was important to seal the sense of rage and power, a true sense of jihad, after the drug had worn off. The Commander's supply of the tablets was limited and the lessons of desert guerrilla warfare had to be rushed. He wondered about the leadership of the troop.

Ahreed soon noticed how the younger boys had gathered their beds around him during the night. He could also see jealous eyes watching him from the older boys across the floor. Suddenly there was screaming from the next room, moving out onto the street. The boys mustered and began to move to the open doorway.

The Commander called his sergeant, the boy about thirteen years old named Walid, through the doorway of the boarding house where the troop had stayed overnight. "Here is your first virgin," said the Commander to the boy, "Ready and waiting for you to sow the seed of the Jihad."

The boy, his heavy, AK-47 weighing him down in front of his Commander, nodded. He obediently marched over to the Commander's side.

"Take her," said the Commander, gesturing towards the young girl, "Show her the power of the Jihad."

The young boy looked over at the girl, noticing that she was not wearing the Kurdish scarf of an appointed female, realising she was not of marriage age. She seemed to the boy to be only about ten or eleven years old.

"Take her!" demanded the Commander, "Show her the way of the Jihadi virgins," he continued, "She is only a rat of the Kurdish infidels."

The boy hesitated, "But most honourable, " he spoke in Arabic, "She is not of age and is too young."

The Commander drew his pistol from his side in an instant, pointing it straight into the young boy's face. "Show her the way, Sergeant Walid," repeated the Commander.

Still jumpy and confused by memories of the previous day and the effects of the small, white tablet, Ahreed flashed back into slow motion. As the Commander's finger twisted around the weapon and switched the safety, the moment in time became minutes to Ahreed. He recalled Esfir, the Australian bush, target practice and a long discussion.
112111111111111.title: ..the drug wears off

1121111111111111.content:
The ISIS Commander squeezed the trigger of his pistol immediately. The sudden pop of the shot made the whole group of boy soldiers tense up. Walid's head splattered like a pumpkin as his thin, small body flopped onto the sand.

The drug in the tablet had mainly worn off and the troop no longer felt its effects. Most of the boy soldiers were in the age range of eleven to fifteen, and without the hallucinogenic effects of the white tablet, they were simply Muslim boys with strong feelings about protecting children, especially younger sisters and cousins. Being trapped in this ISIS training troop on the outskirts of a small village, surrounded by a desert between Iraq and Syria, had no power over such deep, Muslim values.

Although Australian, Ahreed was no exception. Uncertain whether his senses had fully returned, he was shocked by the sudden execution of Walid but also deeply impacted by the event. Perhaps the drug was still affecting him slightly, for what he was seeing still seemed like slow motion. He quickly tried to comprehend what was happening.

The minds of every boy in the troop pounded as they watched their Commander with disdain. Walid had been a friend to most of them, especially the younger ones.

Ahreed grappled with his options, glancing quickly around the rest of the faces standing there. It seemed there was only one path he could choose: the best in a desperate situation. He stood up suddenly, stepped forward and announced to the Commander, "I will sow the seed of the Jihad in the rat of Allah."

The rest of the troop froze in shock.

Many eyes widened among the boys gathered outside. Some glanced nervously at Ahreed for a moment, before looking back down at the body of Walid. A couple of the boys could not help but look across at the helpless young Kurdish girl. Whispers passed between the rest inside the building.

The Commander looked over at Ahreed, the boy who spoke with a strange accent. "Then take her, and make her your first virgin, Ahreed Al Australi," he demanded.

Ahreed obediently marched over to the Commander, saluted, then turned and bent over, grabbing the little girl by the hair and dragging her away towards the back of the building. She screamed and cursed in Kurdish, kicking her legs and trying to swing her arms at Ahreed.

The grown man smiled slightly, tilting his head as he watched Ahreed. Perhaps this young boy would be a good sergeant to replace Walid, he thought.

Ahreed pulled the little girl into a back room of the building, away from prying eyes. He realised what the Commander expected of him, but his Muslim upbringing would never allow him to commit such a terrible, filthy sin against this little girl.

He also realised she would die at the hand of the Commander anyway. He avoided thinking about what the Commander might have done to her overnight. Ahreed and the other boys had slept so heavily, being exhausted from the battle and confused by that drug, they had perhaps missed her screams from the next room.

He also knew that those twenty or so boys would not survive unless he, Ahreed, became their sergeant, and perhaps eventually their Commander. Ahreed quickly tallied his options again. The brutal reality of the Commander's training reeled inside Ahreed's head.

He turned, looked down and then threw the young Kurdish girl against the wall in the small back room. She wailed. He looked at her, tears welling up in his eyes. Ahreed also knew that if he did not follow his Commander's direction, that he too would be executed, just like young Sergeant Walid just seconds ago.

Ahreed's tear-streaked face looked deep into the little girl's eyes, barely visible in the musty, dim room. Back in Australia, girls were supposed to be equal to boys, he thought. The Caliphate was a different, ancient world of war. She was now petrified and shaking, slowly sinking back down into the rubble strewn corner of the floor.

More flashbacks suddenly bolted through Ahreed's head. He saw Hakim's face, then his boy body flying through the air, the dull thud of that bullet echoing in Ahreed's mind. He felt an overwhelming sense of protectiveness for his fellow boy soldiers. They too were merely children. They too were depending on him now, for their survival. Noone outside knew the moments of this room, right now. There were no prying eyes.

Ahreed decided what he had to do with this girl, and determined one thing he could never do. This girl had lost her whole village, her mother, her father, her brothers and sisters. Outside were a dozen or more young boys depending on him for their survival too, he thought.

He approached the girl and tore her dress and she screamed. He then pulled out his knife and held it above her head and she screamed again. He waved his knife around her body and she screamed, screamed, and screamed on and on each time the long blade flashed near to her. He tortured her only so long as necessary. He had to persuade the listeners outside the door of his obedience to the Commander. He needed to be sure that the Commander would trust him, rather than execute him as well as Walid.

In a swing of his arm, he threw his knife in the air with one hand while grabbing the little girl with his other hand. Catching the knife as it fell to his hand in a different grip, he slashed it across her throat in a single movement. In an instant, her body fell limp to the ground.

For that little girl now, the pain was over. At least, thought Ahreed, she may have died without being raped. At least not by him. He had to accept this was the best decision right now. The Commander might never know the difference.

He leant down and sopped some of her blood in his wet, sweating hand, quickly smearing it over his face to hide his tears. He then grasped her blood stained body by the arm and dragged it out of the back room into the laneway next to the building. Pausing for a moment, he then continued to the larger area out front where the Commander and his boy soldiers were waiting.

He let go of the little girl's body on the dirt in front of his Commander's feet, then stood alert, hard faced, saluting him again. "The rat will burn in hell - GLORY BE TO ALLAH!" he shouted.

A wave of murmurs and whispers swept through the group of his young comrades. The Commander looked down at the girl's half bare, beheaded body at his feet then looked up at Ahreed's eyes. "So we have a new Sergeant for our troop!" He declared.

The troop broke out clapping and began chanting, "Ahreed Al Australi! Ahreed Al Australi!"

Ahreed immediately saluted the Commander for a third time, then turned and marched over to his new place in front of the troop, positioning himself between them and the Commander. Some of them patted his shoulders from behind.

Ahreed was now one of the official elders of the troop, for though young, he was now next in command.

The Commander was impressed by Ahreed's leadership and skill with his weapons. And his obedience seemed beyond question. This Australian boy with the strange Arabic was now an older boy he could trust.

Such a situation was was rare. The Commander had been suspicious of Ahreed at first because of his accent and origin, but he could see this kid was different. Few boys at his stage of manhood survived the rigorous training process of ISIS. Controlling sentimental children was not easy. The sword of fear had to be swung swiftly and fatally so often, it was a struggle to keep the troop's numbers up.

To be an effective, hardened fighting force, young boys needed to be sifted like grain. One day they might meet American Marines. Would they shoot at them, or raise a white flag and ask for a cigarette?

With Ahreed now the sergeant, the other boys were enormously heightened in their confidence. The Commander could see that they trusted and admired Ahreed.

Secretly, many of them trusted this Australian boy far more than they trusted their Commander. For the first time in many months, most of the boys began to believe that maybe, just maybe, they could actually survive this endless, surreal nightmare.
1121111111111111.title: Ahreed steps in...

11211111111111111.content:
A little later, the Commander called Ahreed to his private room. "Here," he gestured, holding out his hand, "Give one of these to each soldier, for their strength."

Ahreed could see two maps and a satellite phone on the floor. Besides some stones holding the edges, there were other stones in various locations on the map.

"Now come here sergeant Ahreed Al Australi," he continued, squatting down at the first map. "The sergeant must always know where to go, in case something happens to me." He pointed at a small stone, placed just outside the Iraqi city of Qasim. "We are close to here. This other pebble, near Al Bukamal, is where the other unit of fighters is, who we travelled with from the south, yes?"

Ahreed nodded, "Al Bukamal is over the border in Syria, Commander?"

"No!" the man snapped back at the boy, "This is no border there any more!"

Ahreed quickly added, "For this is the Holy Caliphate, and within there is no borders," his Arabic beginning to sound poetic.

The Commander paused, closed his eyes, then slowly opened them and looked into Ahreed's. "You are truly a lion cub of ahl as-sunnah, Ahreed Al Australi."
11211111111111111.title: Ahreed continues, hardened...

112111111111111111.content:
"Finally," continued the Commander, "I have my born sergeant!"

He looked over the fourteen year old Sydney boy with a sense of pride. "This is a sign from Allah, Sergeant Ahreed." He paused, looking down. "I have waited so long for my lion, with many falling in battle before you."

Ahreed struggled to keep up with the grown man's rhetoric. "May I ask a question, Commander?"

"Of course, Ahreed Al Australi, speak to me, Karesh," he replied, mentioning his name for the first time.

Ahreed hesitated. "Why do you not make the older boys into sergeants?"

The man looked down, his beard bending on his black scarf, always around his neck. Ahreed watched and waited as the troop's elder fidgeted in the dust on the ground with the tip of his finger.

"Because," mumbled the Commander, "I cannot trust them." The man stood up and began to pace around the smaller room.

"They do what I tell them to do, but they do not have the perfect view of the world in Allah's eyes." The Commander continued to pace in a circle around the room, making Ahreed feel slightly dizzy as he watched. "Allah trusts the lions of the Caliphate, not the survivors who pretend to support the noble banner, but would betray it, if given the power."

Ahreed was confused. This man was barely making sense to him.

"You see, Ahreed Al Australi, those young pups will flee to the master with the most food. But the food of the spirit is the World of Allah!"

The Commander reached into his trouser pocket and awkwardly pulled out a small tin. He unscrewed the lid and immediately lifted the flask to his lips and threw back his head. Ahreed could tell he was drinking.

"Tomorrow night," he continued between sips of his tin, "We will unite with a greater fighting force. We will avenge the betrayals and occupy the city. It will continue to function - not be destroyed as we do to the villages - we will keep it going on."

Commander Karesh continued to walk in slow circles around the small room, but he was becoming less steady on his feet.

"But what the infidels do not understand, Ahreed Al Australi, is that we will rebuild the city, after its defeat: we prepare it like a virgin for the wedding and then later, much later, that city will fall at the call of Allah."

Ahreed was confused by the Commander's ramblings. It was like a language that was half information, half religious text. But Ahreed had also learned to watch for symbolic terms.

He wondered if the Commander was actually talking about re-organization of the defeated city, some type of preparation for another event in the future. The religious references appeared to replace the factual information: when the Commander could not say precisely where or what he was talking about, he could simply refer back to religious text. In the future, the religious text could contain the commands, by a type of special interpretation.

In the future, he thought, Commander Karesh could simply call out 'The Virgin is ready for Marriage,' and the city would react to assist the ISIS unit. Ahreed thought hard about his new situation. He was beginning to understand the language of the jihadists well, plus he was gaining important information that would be useful for ASIO back in Australia.

Though sometimes Ahreed wondered if he would ever see Australia, or meet an Australian again. Human life was cheap on this battlefield. Little girls, boy soldiers, old people: nothing was sacred to these monsters.

He watched as his Commander's bloodshot eyes slowly began to close over. It was only the second time he had seen the Commander drink and Ahreed noticed that the rumours about alcohol were true: it made people talk.

Ahreed's father, brother and sister would never drink alcohol. He pondered for moment on some of the conversations he had with his brother, Ahrou. His brother definitely had some interest in the jihad, for now Ahreed could see clearly the special language jihadists used to maintain secrecy, while at the same time give commands.

Ahreed could now also see that the Commander was vital for the survival of the troop. Without the Commander, Ahreed would be left as Sergeant with a group of older boys who he could not trust. Ahreed realised he had to organise the boys who trusted him to defend themselves. If something happened to the Commander, thought Ahreed, then the young boys would not be treated well by the older boys.
112111111111111111.title: the ISIS strategy

1121111111111111112.content:
For some reason, Ahreed had thought the Commander would be leading their troop to unite with other troops, then attack the city. Instead, the troop marched through the day and then lay down near a small village. The Commander had turned to Ahreed and told the boy he was in command, then disappeared into the night.

Ahreed was frightened by the Commander's decree, then soon realised that most of the troop was asleep anyway.

Ahreed approached one side of the camp, to organise watch for the night between the older boys in the troop.

"Ahhhh, Ahreed, Sergeant Ahreed, how are you?" said a voice from the circle. "Come here, sit with us." The figure shuffled to make space on the sand in the darkness.

Ahreed knew it was Mustafa. He was 17 years old and not usually very friendly towards Ahreed.

"It's good to see you, Sergeant Ahreed Al Australi." Mustafa looked at Ahreed as the boy sat down, his hand firmly gripping the mouth piece of the pipe as he spoke. "Do you like a smoke, Ahreed?" asked Mustafa, gesturing towards the main pipe sitting on the sand in the middle of the circle of very young men.

"Not tonight, soldier, but I must talk with you." The circle of older boys laughed at Ahreed's Arabic accent. "We have a mission in the night, so I need your help. We must place two watches, one to the west and one to the south."

Mustafa's eyes widened, "Ooooh, Sergeant, it sounds serious, ha ha" and the others laughed along with him.

"No, not really, but the Commander has asked me to organise a watch, to the west and to the south." Ahreed stood his ground.

Mustafa simply sat, looking at Ahreed. "How do you propose we man this watch, Sergeant?" He was challenging the younger boy. "I would be very happy to spend the night with you Sergeant Ahreed, ha ha.."

The other older boys laughed, all of them looking across at him through the darkness.

Ahreed had tensed. Mustafa had placed his big hand on Ahreed's upper leg. There were more chuckles from the other older boys sitting in the circle.

"You're a very nice young boy, Ahreed Al Australi..."

"You have more experience than me," replied Ahreed carefully, standing up suddenly, "Please organise yourselves: continuous watch, to the west and to the south."

Mustafa smiled a little. "And what call shall we use?" Then he wolf-whistled. The other older boys burst out laughing again.

"Approach alert," replied Ahreed quickly, "This is a defensive alert but take care - they might also be our soldiers."

Mustafa looked down, still smiling, then nodded his head slowly. "Ok, we'll keep watching!" he announced, to another burst of laughter from the others in the circle.

"Thank you Mustafa, our Assad," said Ahreed, "We need protection in this night."

Mustafa nodded again, stood up and walked into the darkness, glancing back at Ahreed once or twice, still smiling.

Ahreed pretended not to notice. He shuffled away across the sand to his north-easterly watch position.
1121111111111111112.title: the city is taken

11211111111111111121.content:
As the birds began to chirp and the desert began to awaken, Ahreed shook his head again to keep alert. It was time for morning prayer, and he suddenly remembered his beloved second Baba, Esfir. He wondered again what might have happened to him back in Libya.

Ahreed also thought for awhile about his real Baba, his life back in Australia and his scholarship at the Kings School in Sydney. He wondered what his brother, Ahrou was doing. He remembered his sister in Melbourne. Almost a tear welled in his eye, but Ahreed pushed his memories away as he reached out for his prayer mat. All of the boys carried a mat.

As Ahreed bowed down to Allah, the first morning beams of sunshine stretched across the desert of Persia. Every morning, it was a sacred moment. Every morning, Ahreed thought about Esfir, his ASIO Baba.

After a few minutes of prayer, Ahreed heard a popping sound in the distance. 'Pop, pop.....pop, pop-pop-pop.'

He leant up from his mat and looked across the rocks into the distance. He could see occasional flashes of light. A second or two later, he would hear the sound. There was a fight happening in the south-western corner of the city. Ahreed's view from the north-east corner of the village camp revealed many suburbs, buildings and slums.

The popping and the flashes in the centre of the city continued, so Ahreed backed away from his post and went to find the other night watchers.

Faithfully, there were still two older boy soldiers keeping watch to the west and to the south. Sixteen year old Abah and fifteen year old Kahliah were awake and detected Ahreed's approach as the sergeant snuck around the camp from the first watch to the second.

Ahreed mentioned to them how impressed he was by their ability to detect his approach. They laughed at him, half appreciating his gesture, but also half resenting his authority. He was just fourteen years old, yet he had the authority to take control of the troop overnight?

A voice from behind spoke suddenly. "Sergeant Ahreed is such a big man now." It was Mustafa. Ahreed did not move or turn. There may be a gun pointing at his head.

Mustafa continued, "The big man who did not know he was followed."

Ahreed focussed on the exact position of the voice behind him, moving his hand slowly but without bending his elbow until he reached the front of his belt.

"I could have cut your throat, Sergeant Ahreed..." Mustafa persisted, " So what - "

In three swift movements Ahreed spun, ducked and jumped, slashing his knife through the voice of Mustafa. The big boy fell to the ground, Ahreed on top. Blood spurted from the throat and Ahreed leapt off him and shook blood from his hand, stepping back towards the others without even looking down at the fresh carcass of Mustafa.

Ahreed inserted his knife back into his belt after a quick wipe. Without knowing whether their Commander would return, Ahreed had no choice. For the sake of the others, Mustafa was now just rat food.

The 'Pop, pop, pop' continued in the distance, and Ahreed knew it was some kind of attack in the city. At any time his troop may be called to fight. He could not lose the trust of the older boys. His jihadi training pointed the way to testing the others later. He stood in front of Abah and Kahliah and paused before speaking.

"I am Ahreed Al Australi, and I command that you, the Lions of Allah, move forward to protect our lion cubs, by securing our north-eastern camp border."

The older Abah suddenly felt obliged to follow the command. "Yes, Sergeant Ahreed, we will secure the north-east." The older boy was shaking.

Ahreed now had a reliable ally in the ranks of the older child soldiers.
11211111111111111121.title: Morning Prayer

112111111111111111211.content:
Ahreed watched as one of his youngest soldiers scrambled over the rocks around the camp and ran up to him. His name was Miyaz.

"Abah reports that there is an approach from the north-east, coming from the city." The boy, Miyaz, was not much older than 10, but was very reliable.

Ahreed thought for a moment and then replied to his little messenger: "Tell Abah to be careful; tell him to be diligent; tell him to look for the black scarf. If there is no black scarf, take the intruder as an infidel."

"Understood," replied the child, "Delivering your message to the watch, Sergeant Ahreed." The boy then disappeared over the rocks like a young fox.

Ahreed was becoming concerned about his Commander. He stooped over and made his way towards the younger troop. "Ready your weapons," he whispered to the huddled group of boys as they gathered around him, "We have an approach from the north-east."

The visitor had a black scarf, arriving escorted by Miyaz. "Ahreed Al Australi?"

"Yes brother, " replied Ahreed to the stranger.

"I am impressed by your troop, Sergeant Ahreed. Your Commander speaks highly of you. I am Commander Rashaad of the third troop. Overnight the 'Hasara' have swarmed the city. It will become our new stronghold."

Rashaad reached into his jacket and pulled out a map. Pointing as he spoke, he continued. "Your task, Sergeant Ahreed, is to command the street patrols. All the people of the city must learn to explain themselves when questioned. If they do not, shoot them."

"Of course," replied Ahreed quickly, "It is done."

Upset with his ASIO mentor at the time, angrily he had yelled at Esfir, "Survival is not dying in your holy fucking war for holy fucking ASIO!"

Esfir quietly replied, "Survival is not just staying alive because you are afraid to die." Esfir took another careful step. "Jihadists believe survival is dying for a good reason." He stopped and waited for a reply from the boy.

"What could be a good reason to die?" mumbled Ahreed.

"Some believe for the rule of Islamic law, some believe it is the gateway to heaven and life everlasting, some just believe in getting seven virgins, or ten virgins for themselves." Esfir paused.

"That's just stupid," Ahreed mumbled to himself. "What do you believe survival is.... Baba?"

Esfir reached Ahreed and continued, "I believe that you only deserve to survive if you have a good reason to LIVE."

Ahreed had been avoiding eye contact with Esfir, but he suddenly looked up into his eyes. "What is a good reason to live, baba?"

Esfir thought carefully. This was a delicate moment for the boy. "One good reason to live..." he took a deep breath, "..is because you can help another to survive if you can survive."

Ahreed stared into the man's eyes. He thought over what Esfir had said a few times.

"It is not enough to lay down your life for another, Arghree. You should live your life to save the lives of others." Esfir rocked back and forth a little, searching for better words. "Life can be good, Arghree, so it is right to protect it."

Ahreed thought hard, then asked Esfir, "Why must it be ME? I am only fourteen years old, baba."

"Because Arghree," Esfir chose his words carefully, "There are so many only fourteen - and younger even - who want to die for the survival of the jihad. They blindly follow men who do not care about them. Men who build armies of youth, but never fight. They offer them glory, fame, virgins and honour, but they do not seem to want these things for themselves."

Ahreed closed his eyes.

Ahreed stopped, looking into the eyes of the Commander. The man waited for a moment, then asked Ahreed in Arabic, "What is the next step to taking this village?"

"Move through the buildings, Commander," replied Ahreed, "Kill any sniper and seek out the virgins of Allah."

The man smiled, slowly turned and then walked away from the dead heaps of the baby and her mother in the middle of the dirt street. Ahreed turned and looked back at the buildings, their windows and rooftops. The rest of the troop was watching Ahreed. The young sergeant seems to imitate Ahreed's every move. They were astounded at his actions after the white pill and it was obvious he was ready to kill anything that moved. Ahreed lifted his heavy AK-47 up and marched towards the first doorway he saw.

The other boy soldiers did the same. A few of them glanced back at Ahreed with widened eyes as they chose their direction. Some were afraid. Others, especially the younger boys, thought he might be a blessing.

Ahreed had no doubt he would shoot anything that moved behind his doorway. His legs and arms now easily carried the heavy metal of the gun, while any door in his face he would kick down. The effects of the little white tablet had really kicked in now, and he was angry about the loss of young Hakim and determined to avenge him. Nothing else mattered.

The Commander paused, turning and looking back at Ahreed as he yelled at the door with his strange accent. The Commander had noticed Ahreed's astounding skill with a weapon and was impressed by his ruthlessness. Just a few moments earlier he had wondered if Ahreed was going to attack him.

112111111111112.title: Ahreed ignores the slaughter...

1121111111112.content:
The first real shot Ahreed fired was from a small handgun. Though he was wearing earmuffs, the sudden bolt of thunder and flash of lightning shocked the boy. He panted for minute or two after the bullet cut a clean hole in the paper behind the pumpkin.

Pausing, he turned to his teacher. "Why the pumpkin, uncle?" He asked Esfir.

"Do not call me uncle, Arghree - you must call me baba, always." The ASIO veteran took a breath before continuing, "You will see why the pumpkin, when you hit it."

Esfir put his hand on the boy's shoulder, his other on the boy's hand, leaning his face in close to Ahreed's. His new son needed to be comfortable close with him as well as learn to shoot. "Now be steady and strong, and remember, the lion does not hunt with one eye closed. Use both eyes when you aim close."

"BANG!" went the gun again, and the pumpkin splattered in all directions. Esfir was amazed that the boy hit the pumpkin on only his second attempt.

"There," pointed Esfir, "Now you see the difference. When it is heavy and wet, it explodes - just like a man's head."

Ahreed suddenly dropped the gun, grabbed his stomach and bent over, vomiting on the concrete floor.

Esfir waited.

Sitting back up, Ahreed tilted his head at Esfir. "How can you say such a thing?" he protested, panting and with tears in his eyes, "I would NEVER shoot a man's head! A man's life is sacred before Allah!" he declared.

Esfir grabbed the boy's shoulders and forced him to turn around. "Look at me, Arghreed, LOOK AT ME! What if the man is about to shoot you, huh? What if he is about to shoot me, your baba eh? "

"You are NOT my baba!" Yelled back Ahreed, angry now.

"What if he was going to shoot your real baba, then? Eh?" Fired back Esfir. "What if some crazy jihadist has gun at your head and tells you 'if you do not shoot, I SHOOT YOU!' Huh? It's not so simple, kid!"

"You said I would not be a soldier!" Yelled back the boy, spitting and trying to get rid of the taste of vomit from his mouth.

"A soldier no, no. But in dangerous places there are bad people, bad things. You must SURVIVE, Arghree! Continued Esfir, still holding the boy's shoulders.

The angry youth pulled away from his teacher. "I can survive without your guns, your fake family, and your fucking ASIO!" Ahreed ran back to the stairs leading up to the house. He turned and called back at Esfir with fire in his eyes, " And stop calling me Arghree! Only my REAL Baba calls me that!" Then he stumbled onto the stairs and desperately started climbing to the light of the open room above.

Esfir constrained his urge to chase after the boy, instead squatting down to the floor and shaking his head. What could he do? This kid was just fourteen and a pampered Australian youth.

As Ahreed reached the top of the stairs he stopped, almost unable to breathe. His legs began to wobble beneath him uncontrollably, forcing Ahreed to grab hold of the railing. He sank down to the floor.

Esfir waited at the bottom of the stairs, listening. He could the boy panting at the top of the stairs.

Ahreed flopped on the floor, turning over at looking up at the ceiling still enraged and now hiccuping with fear, shame and desperation. He still felt sick in his guts.

Esfir kept waiting. It took several minutes for the boy to quieten down. Finally, he called up the staircase, "And what is survival, Ahreed?"

The boy started to breathe heavily again. Angrily, he yelled up at the roof, "Survival is not dying in your holy fucking war for holy fucking ASIO!"

Rising slowly step by step, Esfir quietly replied, "Survival is not just staying alive because you are afraid to die." Esfir took another step up, carefully listening. "Jihadists believe survival is dying for a good reason." He stopped and waited for a reply from the boy.

"What could be a good reason to die?" mumbled Ahreed.

"Some believe for the rule of Islamic law, some believe it is the gateway to heaven and life everlasting, some just believe in getting seven virgins, or ten virgins for themselves." Esfir paused.

"That's just stupid," Ahreed mumbled to himself. "What do you believe survival is.... Baba?"

Esfir took a few steps until he reached Ahreed lying on the floor at the top of the stairs. "I believe," he began, "That you only deserve to survive if you have a good reason to LIVE."

Ahreed had been avoiding eye contact with Esfir, but he suddenly looked up into his eyes. "What is good reason to live, baba?"

Esfir thought carefully. This was a delicate moment for the boy. "One good reason to survive..." he took a deep breath, "..is because you can help another to survive if you can survive."

Ahreed stared into the man's eyes. He thought over what Esfir had said a few times.

"It is not enough to lay down your life for another, Arghree. You should live your life to save the lives of others." Esfir rocked back and forth a little, searching for better words. "Life can be good, Arghree, so it is good to protect it."

Ahreed thought hard, then asked Esfir, "Why must it be ME? I am only fourteen years old, baba."

"Because Arghree," Esfir chose his words carefully, "There are so many only fourteen - and younger even - who want to die for the survival of the jihad. They blindly follow men who do not care about them. Men who build armies of youth, but never fight. They offer them glory, fame, virgins and honour, but they do not seem to want these things themselves."

Ahreed closed his eyes.

As Russell left the room, the Kirstin entered. Ahreed looked deeper down into his lap, determined not to say any more to her.

"So, Ahreed," she began, looking at the boy, "Your mother was murdered by terrorists.." she trailed off, expectantly.

Ahreed pretended he did not hear the question.

"That must have been difficult for you, Ahreed," Kirstin continued, "It must have made you angry."

The boy kept looking down, freezing his body and not moving at all.

Kirstin persisted with her line of questions. "So your Baba must be angry too, is that right?"

Ahreed wavered in his chair, becoming more and more angry. He wanted to yell at the woman, Kirstin. Instead he just kept ignoring her.

"And your Baba, a mister Akram Hussein, has been organising a bombing in Melbourne?" Kirstin darted at the boy.

Ahreed looked up at the woman suddenly, anger welling in his tears. His lower face shivering, he answered, "My Baba told me those people were EVIL!" he yelled. "MY BABA SAID, if you ever do anything like this, Ahreed, I will forget you. My Baba said to me, this action will cause all Muslims to be treated badly in Australia, like you are treating ME NOW!" He held the woman's stare for a moment, then looked back down.

Kirstin relaxed and turned over to the next page in her notes. "So you don't know about your father's involvement in the terror attacks in Melbourne?" she again looked at the boy, awaiting his gaze.

Ahreed lost control. He did not know how to listen or to speak, but started rambling, "My Baba is a good Australian - he told me this country is good and that he came here to protect me and my brother and my sister. My Baba says the government is good, and that my sister will be a doctor one day because of this government.... but why why does this government bring me here? Why do you torture me??" he finished, panting, almost hysterical.

Kirstin scribbled a note or two onto the page she was reading. She paused, looked up at Ahreed, his eyes aflamed with anger staring back at her. "You call this torture, Ahreed?"

The boy looked away to the side. He glanced around the room, then back into his lap.

Kirstin placed her notes down on the stainless steel desk and leant forward, pointing her pen across at Ahreed's face, "You don't even know what torture is, young man."

Ahreed was still panting with rage and fear. He kept looking down. He felt he was in prison, being persecuted by a government who hated Muslims like him. This woman was twisting his words, confusing him. He was afraid to say anything more, but uncontrollably blurted, "Torture is taking me away from home - you have taken me against my will!"

Kirstin held the boy's gaze, and speaking quietly she said, "No, Ahreed, I'm just doing my job. We must question you."

The boy snapped his gaze back down into his hands, fidgeting in his lap. He could never believe that his Baba was responsible for the Melbourne attack plan. It simply was not possible to him.

Kirstin pressed further, "What other kinds of torture are you expecting from us, Ahreed?"

He began to imagine his worst thoughts of what torture meant. He thought about beheading, the sound of a cow as the knife was dragged across its neck. He thought about being shot in a firing squad. He thought about his Baba, yelling at him with a knife in his hand. For a brief moment, he saw a vision of his mother, blood all over her dress, lying on the ground reaching out to him.

Kirstin watched the boy's face. Ahreed was very distressed - she could see that. She waited, watching the tears run down his brown cheeks.

Ahreed looked from side to side. He shook his head, took a breath, then pointed his finger onto the stainless steel table in front of him. "This is torture, Miss Kirstin..." he began, "This is pain. I do not know the answers to your questions."

Kirstin glanced back down at her notes casually, flipping the page. "Okay, Ahreed, but I need to know what you think we are going to do to you?"

Ahreed paused. He looked up at the woman, Kirstin. He looked around the room again. He looked back at her. She looked young, with dark hair and flashing eyes. Her face seemed hard, looking back into his eyes. But there was something else. There was something behind her brown eyes and skin, a closeness he had not felt before.

"I do not know, Miss Kirstin," answered Ahreed, glancing down then back up at the young woman. "I cannot imagine."

Suddenly the door opened and Russell re-entered the room. Kirstin stood up and the two gestured at their notes as Russell sat down. Kirstin closed the door, but remained at the side of the table.

"We are very sorry to put you through this, Ahreed," began Russell, "But it was necessary for us to ask you these things before we move to the next stage."

Ahreed glanced between the two of them. "What do you mean, the next stage?" he asked.

"Your new family, Ahreed," continued Russell. "We have a new Baba for you back in Sydney."

Ahreed was suddenly distressed again, "But my Baba..."

Kirstin interrupted Ahreed, "Your Baba will always be there, Ahreed. We will not take him away from you."

Russell, picking up the conversation added,"We need you to come and work for us. Your dad already works for us and we need you to become a new source of information."

Ahreed was calming down, but still confused. "What information do you want from me? I know nothing about the Melbourne stadium terror plot."

Kirstin spoke in reply, "But you do, Ahreed. You know many things. Once you are trained by your teacher, you will understand many more things."

"Who is my teacher?" the boy replied.

"His name is Esfir, and he is from Iran, just like your Baba is..." added Russell. "He will guide you, but you need to pretend to be his son."

Ahreed was still confused. "But my Baba?" he asked.

Kirstin moved over to the steel desk and leant down to Ahreed. "Your Baba will always be your Baba, Ahreed. You will see him, talk with him, spend time with him. We will make sure of that."

Slowly, Ahreed began to calm down. So much had happened today, and in an instant it seemed like his whole life had changed. Yet somehow, he had always known deep down that he was going to be connected with the troubles of the Australian Muslims. It was as though his Baba had prepared him. He realized that the sudden departure of his sister to Melbourne, the beginning of his high school at the King's School in Sydney, all of it was connected.

"We're sorry, Ahreed," repeated Kirstin, "But we had to ask you certain questions."

Russell added, "And I was the good cop, while Kirstin had to be the bad cop, Ahreed...that's why she seemed so nasty." Russell gestured with his hand towards the notes on the table in front of him, "It was the procedure we had to follow."

Ahreed could feel his heart slowing down. For the first time since this afternoon, he was calmer again. Still, he was uncertain what all of this meant.

112122.content:
Aaron Teasdale was 47 years old. He had been a supervisor in the Australian Secret Service for nearly twenty years. He started as a state policeman in the New South Wales Police at Yass, a country town on the main highway between Sydney and Melbourne, later transferring to the Australian Federal Police at the nearby national capital, Canberra.

Throughout his career, Aaron had been assigned missions that involved families and children. The Australian Secret Service had been very busy in this area of families because of boat people people arriving on Australia's northern shores for several years.

Most of his assignments were about security threats and falsified stories of refugees from Asia and the Middle East. This latest case however, seemed far more intense. He read through the eleven points of required training for this fourteen year old Sydney boy, Ahreed Hussein al Isfahan.

It was not the first time that Teasdale had seen a child brought into the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation as an operative: through the years several kids had been placed into his files, assisting ASIO with the monitoring of family and extended family members. However, it was most peculiar that a child psychologist was not appointed to oversee the boy's progress.

The eleven points of training had been recently updated - within the last few hours - and Teasdale clicked on the reference icon to compare it with this new case. To his surprise, the PDF file was a breakdown of the eleven known stages of training for a jihadi youth. In other words, an analysis of the radicalisation process of adolescents known to be used by ISIS.

Comparing the two, he could see immediately that the boy's training program was modelled on the known Jihadi method. Trouble was, no one had been appointed to oversee the boy's welfare. Teasdale knew this was illegal.

He sat back in his office chair and nervously rubbed his chin. He knew there was something he should do about this. He knew it was not fair or reasonable to put a fourteen year old boy through this program. Beginning with point one, the list of steps read:

"1/ Sever emotional support system of family, broad community, schooling, and all trust-based support systems: ensure the sense of abandonment emotionally affects the youth."

Teasdale shook his head. This stuff was torture to a kid. There was also a note about the updated training program: it explained that the activation of the Sydney kid was to be accelerated and that it was to follow, as near as possible, the Jihadi method instead of the 'usually time demanding process' used for children who became connected to the Intelligence Organisation.

The officer knew he had to do something about this illegal program, but in the meantime he needed to authorise the requested immediate and urgent transfer of the boy, who currently held no Australian passport. The kid, Ahreed Hussein, had been introduced to his 'new' father but it was, like, an hour ago. The schedule was to have the two operatives on the ground, in Libya, within just 72 hours! I was ludicrous!

The only way the mission was possible was if Teasdale authorised the 'Hughs'. It was a high-speed, low noise helicopter that was capable of night flight, necessary to move the pair to Brisbane within a couple of days for the long, international flight into Athens, Greece. The request was to occupy the Hughs for about 5 days.

While Teasdale quickly realised the Hussein case was extraordinary, it was not necessary for him to bring it to an immediate halt. He had several days, and there was no reason to alert anyone to his objection right now, he thought. Since the Melbourne terror threat on ANZAC Day, several of these peculiar programs had emerged. The officer was weary of getting in the way of Homeland Security.

Instead he would make some administrative diversions appear, such as DNA profiling of the child, facial recognition registration, fingerprinting and so on. These were all absolute requirements of ASIO, and he would simply ensure these procedures were followed. To the letter.

This would, in theory, delay the deployment of this young Hussein, so that Teasdale could make his case for diversion of that deployment. He felt it necessary to review the training program with the overview of a child psychologist.

After all, there would need to be a snapshot of the boy's personality recorded, as required for the debriefing process later when Ahreed came off his first assignment. How do you judge the psychological effects of the assignment without an analysis of what is 'normal' for this particular individual?

It was simply not fair - nor lawful - for the Australian Secret Intelligence Organisation to place a young Australian boy under this much duress - no matter how vital the assignment!

Sonia Rodriguez was 52 years old, a veteran of the Australian Secret Service and impatient with this man in her office. His daily ASIO conference was 1120am, which she knew from his unit code: one-one-two, and she knew he was ninth in command of his unit, being 'one-one-two-nine'.

The earlier in the day the conference, the more important the assignment portfolio within ASIO. Information was organised and compartmentalised for security in this way, on a daily basis in the Australian Secret Service.

This also allowed Rodriguez to consider Teasdale's rank, one-one-two/nine in relation to her own, zero-six-three/two. Those with a zero at the beginning of their ID tended to be very high ranking. They decided the direction of ASIO on a daily basis. However Teasdale's conference time was adjusted to Middle Eastern time and he was ninth in command of that unit. She was second in command of hers. But the importance of Teasdale's unit was uncertain to her.

Rodriguez glanced back briefly over Teasdale's submission then clicked through to another window, showing a brief overview of Teasdale's personality and history. She had access to the personnel files of all the people she dealt with in the Organisation.

Teasdale was taking some time to answer. "...Well, 063-2, I am concerned about the compromise of the welfare of this young Australian boy."

Rodriguez clicked through to yet another window on her computer. It showed the day's current order of priorities for the Australian Secret Intelligence Organisation. A local threat of a mass gassing at a sporting stadium in Melbourne still dominated the agenda. It had been dominating for a long time. It was obvious to Rodriguez why the boy's deployment had been so dramatically accelerated. She could see the bigger picture.

"You are aware," Rodriguez began, "That there is an agreement between Australian Security and the boy's father?"

"Yes," replied Teasdale patiently, "But I am required to get a child psychologist's review filed before his deployment. It's for the child's welfare, and for the sake of debriefing the boy, post-operation. We cannot assess him properly after each mission if we do not have a psychological review prior to deployment. We need to compare the two, before and after, to assess risk for new assignments in the future, and so it goes on."

" 'The thread of continuous assessment'," began Rodriguez, attempting to quote policy..

"Yes, 'continuous, comparative assessment', six-three-two," corrected Teasdale. He had written the policy: he knew the exact words.

Rodriguez was concerned about the credibility of Teasdale's argument. This operation he was questioning dated back many years, involving too many deep-cover agents. These highly hidden agents of ASIO, Teasdale knew nothing about. They were a radical, almost desperate approach to counter-terrorism after '9/11'. Should terrorism break out on Australian soil, it had always been the plan to activate these cells of anti-terrorism established by ASIO in Australia.

The bombing of a popular night club for Australian tourists in Bali, Indonesia had not been enough to activate this operation, though it came close. A few minor incidents on home soil, then suddenly an imminent threat within Australia at a huge sports stadium. Plus, the intelligence suggested a gas attack. This had sent the higher ranks of ASIO into near panic mode.

She quickly weighed up the situation. A young teenager activated according to a long-term plan; the terror threat on local ground; the capacity for ASIO to judge accurately the state of mind of the operative in the future...

Reluctantly, she nodded. Although she was eager to assist her superiors and activate Ahreed quickly, she could not deny the importance of a psychological analysis of the boy's state of mind. Teasdale spoke well but it was obvious he had never been an active operative in the field. Rodriguez considered his email and his stated position, typing some notes into the file as she thought.

Although Rodriguez had little concern for Teasdale's basic objection, it was valid and had to be adhered to. "Very well, " she spoke, "We will delay determining the date of activation of Ahreed until your child psych review is completed." She typed a few more sentences into the file.

"Ok," continued Russell on the end of the line, "The boy is being airlifted directly to you immediately."

Esfir was confused. "What about his induction?" he asked.

There was some hesitation on the phone line, "It's been given to you to look after," replied Russell, sounding frustrated.

"That is a sudden change in plan, yes?" asked Esfir, "And how does the boy feel about this?"

There was more hesitation. "He doesn't know yet," Russ replied.

Esfir paused. This was a very big responsibility he was about to take on. Russell was asking him to both induct the 14 year old boy plus give him cover in the local community in Sydney. "Alright," he agreed, "But this is a lot of work - you know this?"

"Yeah, yeah..." continued Russ, "We know it's a big ask, Esfir. But there's orders from above about rapid deployment of the asset."

"Asset?" questioned Esfir, "He is a fourteen year old boy!" Esfir was not really upset, but he felt he should show some concern while agreeing to the proposal. "What about our family in Melbourne - can't they take him? There are two operatives, husband and wife to look after the child?"

"That remains an option, one-nine." was the reply on the phone. The childless Muslim couple in Melbourne would be an ideal placement for young Ahreed, but Russell was sensing a change in the whole direction of the deployment.

"And does this child, Arghreed, look like me? You think us Muslims all look the same?"

There was a pause on the phone. "He has to stay in Sydney and move to the 'mozzie' school, Esfir.... we need to find leads into the Melbourne bombings threat quickly and we suspect it came from Sydney." Russell knew more than he was revealing.

Esfir paused again. "I suppose so..." he continued, slowly, "I will do this for our organisation, agent one-four."

Russell, still at the Canberra headquarters of ASIO, breathed a sigh of relief. "We'll send him directly, by chopper."

Esfir became falsely upset again: "Why you send chopper to my house at night - the neighbours wonder who I am??"

Russell was expecting some resistance. "We need to get him started straight away, one-nine," he replied officially, "He flies out in five days."

Esfir was shocked. Five days? How on earth could he prepare a 14 year old boy for espionage in five days? Anyway, he had already agreed to the assignment, according to the code of ASIO. Esfir shook his head.

Russell was waiting on the line. "Esfir?" he called.

"Yes, yes..." Esfir replied, "I will take the boy tonight and begin immediately - fly out in five days."

"Confirmed, one-one-five, one-nine." Russell terminated the call.

At ASIO in Canberra, Russell turned and looked at the boy through the mirror glass and sighed. He and Kirstin had just broken a promise: to return Ahreed to his family immediately.

Not just any maths teacher, Mr Bhaduri headed straight for the Principal's office as the King's School ended its day. He wanted to know where his star pupil was. While crossing the quadrangle to Mr Waites' office, he noticed Ahrou Hussein walking on the opposite path. Mr Bhaduri diverted to a crossing and met the young man as he walked with his friends. "Ahrou, have you seen your brother?"

"Ahreed? No, not today since the bus, Mr Bhaduri." replied Ahrou. "Maybe he's doing something for music.. a concert rehearsal, Mr Bhaduri."

The maths teacher glanced across the quadrangle, but not seeing any boys Ahreed's age, decided to press on to the Principal's office. He began to pass by as he continued, "Ok, perhaps you are correct, Ahrou. I will see you tomorrow night at the centre, yes?" Mr Bhaduri merged into the tide of other students going heading home.

The young man called to the teacher as he disappeared into the crowd, "Yes Sir, seven o'clock," with a thumbs up and nodding gesture.

Mr Bhaduri stepped into the office reception, the noise of the passing students tapering off as the glass door closed behind him. "Eileen," he approached the desk, "Is Professor Waites still in his office? Can I speak with him?"

The receptionist picked up her phone, "Hold on, Mr Bhaduri, I'll check."

Bhaduri glanced out through the windows across the quadrangle as he waited, watching Ahrou laughing and joking with friends outside. The maths teacher noted how engaged Ahrou seemed to be. This was an important indicator of progress. It was important that the student break away from his peer support group, finding greater closeness with the centre.

"Mr Waites can speak with you Mr Bhaduri," interrupted the receptionist.

Without replying, Bhaduri ushered himself in. "Professor Waites, I'm concerned about a student, Ahreed Hussein. He did not appear for his maths test today?"

The principal shuffled away a piece of paper his was holding while seated at his desk. "Did you check with Eileen if he was absent, Mr Bhaduri?"

Bhaduri hesitated, "No, but I am sure I saw him in the yard, earlier in the day."

Mr Waites looked down, recalling the special conditions in his briefing by the ASIO agents earlier in the day. After a brief hestitation, he replied, "Then check with Eileen, and if you are not mistaken send the year level coordinator an email, Mr Bhaduri." Waites then looked down and repositioned his glasses on the end of his nose to read another sheet of paper in front of him.

The maths teacher was embarrassed. It seemed the Principal was impatient with him for not following the proper channels. Bhaduri hesitated before turning to leave, "I'm sorry, Professor, but his brother Ahrou also told me he was here.... I was.. concerned."

"Thank you, Mr Bhaduri," replied Waites, nodding as he looked back down at the papers in front of him.

Bhaduri made his way out briskly. He made a mental note to remain calmer in future. It was important that he did not seem to be over-interested in these special students of his.

Ahreed paused for a moment. "Because you are taking me away."
The sound of the traffic outside filled the silence as she looked up at the rear vision mirror. Ahreed could see her eyes meet the man's as he drove.

"Where do you think we are taking you?" asked the woman, glancing back out of the passenger window. She seemed to be half ignoring Ahreed.

He looked down into his lap, feeling frustrated now, as well as frightened. Every question he asked was returned by another question. "How could I know, when you have not told me!?" he demanded, letting the two of them know he was becoming upset.

The woman smiled again, still staring distantly out at the bustling city of Sydney passing by.

Ahreed kept waiting for an answer. Neither the man nor the woman replied. Ahreed was afraid to ask any more questions. He looked around the car instead and noticed a sign stuck to the driver's visor. Ahreed realised it was a hire car.

He so wanted to ask again about his destination, but his trust in the two strangers had been exhausted by the conversation leaving the Kings School.

The woman beside him and the man driving kept ignoring him. The woman just reached into her handbag and took out a small tablet device, then started texting.

"Calm down, Ahreed," replied the woman, "We're just going on a quick flight to Canberra."

"Stay calm, Ahreed," she said, raising her voice slightly and placing her smartphone down on the next seat. "It's going to be alright...there's no need to be alarmed."
"But what is this!?" protested Ahreed. "You can't do this to me... this is Australia."

What happened next really worried Ahreed. Instead of driving to a carpark, the vehicle drove under an overpass and was suddenly on the tarmac. There were people walking all around outside and Ahreed quickly considered his escape options. A plane appeared right in front of the car as it stopped.

She knew if they gave chase they would create a commotion in the air freight area, which could easily ring out across the entire airport's alarm system. "We have to.." she explained, "..otherwise we'll create an official incident."

Kirstin turned from Russell and started speaking to the device. "One-one-five, one-one, Kirstin." Her check in code passed immediately and a voice at ASIO Headquarters replied. The code advised HQ that she was agent 11, her rank, while 1-1-5 described her unit and its daily check-in time of 11:50am. So the agent at the other end knew immediately that the matter was urgent because it was now 4:45pm, not Unit 1-1-5's usual contact period of the day.

Aaron Teasdale was 47 years old. He had been a supervisor in the Australian Secret Service for nearly twenty years. He started as a state policeman in the New South Wales Police at Yass, a country town on the main highway between Sydney and Melbourne, later transferring to the Australian Federal Police at the nearby national capital, Canberra.

Throughout his career, Aaron had been assigned missions that involved families and children. The Australian Secret Service had been very busy in this area of families because of boat people people arriving on Australia's northern shores for several years.

Most of his assignments were about security threats and falsified stories of refugees from asia and the middle east. This latest mission, however, seemed far more intense. He read through the eleven points of required training for this fourteen year old Sydney boy, Ahreed Hussein al Ahrahed.

It was not the first time that Teasdale had seen a child brought into the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation: through the years several kids had been placed into his files, assisting ASIO with the monitoring of family and extended family members. However, it was most peculiar that a child psychologist was not appointed to oversee the boy's progress.

The eleven points of training had been recently updated - within the last few hours - and Teasdale clicked on the reference icon to compare it with his current assignment. To his surprise, the PDF file was a breakdown of the eleven known stages of training for a jihadi youth. In other words, an analysis of the radicalisation process of adolescents known to be used by ISIS.

Comparing the two, he could see immediately that the boy's training program was modelled on the known Jihadi method. Trouble was, no one had been appointed to oversee the boy's welfare. Teasdale knew this was illegal.

He sat back in his office chair and nervously rubbed his chin. He knew there was something he should do about this. He knew it was not fair or reasonable to put a fourteen year old boy through this program. Beginning with point one, the list of steps read:

"1/ Sever emotional support system of family, broad community, schooling, and all trust-based support systems: ensure the sense of abandonment emotionally affects the youth."

Teasdale shook his head. This stuff was torture to a kid. There was also a note about the updated training program: it explained that the activation of the Sydney kid was to be accelerated and that it was to follow, as near as possible, the Jihadi method instead of the 'usually time demanding process' normally used for children who became connected to the Intelligence Organisation.

While Teasdale quickly realised the Hussein case was extraordinary, it was not necessary for him to bring it to an immediate halt. He had several days, and there was no reason to alert anyone to his objection right now, he thought. There were technicalities with 'deployment' that could stretch the timeline out to several weeks.

He could make some administrative diversions appear, such as DNA profiling of the child, facial recognition registration, fingerprinting and so on. These were all absolute requirements of ASIO, and he would simply ensure these procedures were followed. To the letter.

This would, in theory, delay the deployment of this young Hussein, so that Teasdale could make his case for diversion of that deployment. He felt it necessary to review the training program with the overview of a child psychologist.

After all, there would need to be a snapshot of the boy's personality recorded, as required for the debriefing process later, when Ahreed came off his first assignment. How do you judge the psychological effects of the assignment without an analysis of what is 'normal' for this particular individual?

It was simply not fair - nor lawful - for the Australian Secret Intelligence Organisation to place a young Australian boy under this much pressure - no matter how vital the assignment! Teasdale started typing.

Mr Bhaduri spoke briefly with the House Master at the Kings School boarding house upon his arrival. Explaining his concern for Ahrou, he asked the Master about the young man's recent behaviour. "I don't know, Mr Bhaduri."

The teacher bobbed down to bed level to continue questioning. "How did you get here?"

Ahreed's lip quivered slightly. "I, I escaped from them at Moscot Airport, caught a train and then two busses."

Bhaduri's mind was racing. Was it him they were after? Was Ahrou about to be summoned by ASIO? Bhaduri sat down on the end of the bed and thought hard. But what troubled Bhaduri the most was why Ahreed? The secret service could be monitoring Ahreed's phone right now. "Why didn't you go home, Ahree?"

A tear welled in the boy's eyes. "I was too afraid... what might be there. Once before I went home and the whole house was empty!" He turned to his older brother, "Ahrou, you remember that, yes?"

Ahrou nodded, "Yes Teacher. Baba said the landlord hated us when he found out where we were from and had everything taken out. We had to move to another place."

"And Baba!" sobbed the younger boy, where is Baba? I am too afraid to call him.. in case I get him in t-trouble."

"I can call Baba, Ahreed. Don't worry." Ahrou noticed his teacher catching his gaze. Bhaduri leant back and lifted his finger to his lips so Ahreed could not see.

The teacher thought quickly. "Ahreed, why would ASIO want to hurt you? They probably have someone who has complained, or thought you were suspicious... some busybody who hates Muslims." Bhaduri paused while the boy's older brother waited for their Baba to answer the phone. The maths teacher was very worried about the situation, but it was true that all of it could be nothing.

"Alo, Ahrou?" asked his Baba as he answered.

"Yes, Baba, it's Ahrou."

"Ahrou, do you know where your brother is?" asked his Baba, sounding worried.

"Yes Baba, he is here with me."

"Alhamdulillah!" exclaimed his Baba,"Is he alright?"

"Yes, yes Baba, but he is very frightened. The secret service took him from school," explained Ahrou.

"Let me speak with him, Ahrou, please."

The older boy handed his phone to his young brother. Ahreed spoke with his Baba for several minutes, tears in his eyes again. Mr Bhaduri took Ahrou aside and explained the meeting place for the coming Friday morning. His teacher whispered into his ear, "This is a big moment for Australia, Ahrou. You may become famous throughout the world as well."

Ahrou was shaken by the news. Meeting actual Jihadists for a possible mission could mean his own martyrdom.
12111112.title: Bhaduri sees Ahreed

121111121.content:
Ahreed was still sobbing into Ahrou's phone. "But why, Baba? Why is this? I'm scared they're going to hurt me, Baba.."

Akram Hussein, 67, was worried about his youngest child and knew he had to explain. He'd always known ASIO was coming for Ahreed because the Australian Government had been supporting his whole family since its arrival in Sydney nine years ago. ASIO had also alerted him of their plan to move Ahreed to a new school in this year, but Akram had expected it would be at the end of the year. He assumed the speeding up of the process was because of the Melbourne terror alert he had heard about. Everyone was on edge after the Australian Prime Minister's emergency announcement to the nation about a possible gas attack in a Melbourne sports stadium and an attempt to blow up a city hospital.

His daughter Noora was also studying at Melbourne University while Ahreed and his older brother, Ahrou were attending the Kings School, Sydney's most prestigious secondary college. Noora was doing medicine and Akram and both of his sons, Ahreed and Ahrou were very proud of her. They were also worried about her being in Melbourne.

Because of his previous work with the Iranian Government's nuclear program, Akram and his family were welcomed as refugees, but at a cost. One of his beloved children should give back and Ahreed, even brighter than his older sister, had been chosen before the boy had started high school. He was to do two years at the Kings School, then move to Alnoori Muslim School. If successful at this next process Ahreed was facing right now, he was to become a sleeper cell embedded in the radical Muslim community by ASIO. They were especially interested in the radicalization of young teenaged boys.

The aging engineer had already faced his own struggles in Australia. The fear of detection as an agent by others in the Muslim community, the regular moving of their home for security reasons, the loss of his beloved wife. Having no mother from four years of age, Ahreed too, had suffered. Akram explained all of this to Ahreed for what seemed like hours, though it was really only a precious few minutes.

Meanwhile, Bhaduri had figured out it would be best to wait and see what happened before risking any further communication with his contact in Iraq. Akram arrived late in the night and picked up Ahreed, while Bhaduri explained to Principal Waites what had happened at the boarding house. The maths teacher was surprised when Akram left without taking Ahrou as well.

The conflicting ideals of a modern, secular Australia and a war torn, desperate Middle East confuse and inspire Ahreed. As his youth sets fire to his life, the child within must witness acts no boy should endure. As the man rises from the ashes of an ancient land, he finds a nation racing against time to emerge into the post modern, global culture of one mankind."
